Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Barkley re-joined the Everton first team for the [[2013–14 Everton F.C. season
Jasper, Indiana}}: 2013–14 season]]. He scored his first goal for the club on the opening day in a 2–2 draw against [[Norwich City F.C.
column3: Norwich City]], and was later named man of the match.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Premier League: Everton draw 2–2 with Norwich at Carrow Road
column11: accessdate=18 August 2013}}</ref> During the first half of the season, Barkley put in several man-of-the-match performances, notably against [[Arsenal F.C.
column13: Swansea City]] – the latter whom he scored the winner against.<ref>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=23 December 2013}}</ref> He received praise from many pundits including [[Alan Hansen]] who said Barkley has absolutely everything and [[Gary Lineker]] who claimed he is a star in the making and a prodigious talent.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Everton's Ross Barkley can reach the top, says Alan Hansen
column23: title=Ross Barkley: Everton midfielder can star for England says Lineker

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Barkley's first FA Cup goal came on 4 January 2014, opening a 4–0 win over Queens Park Rangers in the third round.<ref>{{cite news
column8: date=4 January 2014}}</ref> In March, Barkley scored a superb solo goal against [[Newcastle United F.C.
column9: Newcastle United]] in which he ran from his own half to net the opener in a 3–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=4 June 2014}}</ref> On 18 April 2014, he was named as one of the six players on the shortlist for the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] award.<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=PFA Player of the Year award shortlist: Gerrard and Lallana nominated
column20: location=London}}</ref> He scored a total of 6 goals in 34 Premier League matches throughout the season, including a goal against [[Manchester City F.C.
column21: Manchester City]] on 3 May which BBC Sport described as \"spectacular\" and was awarded goal of the season at Everton's end of year awards.<ref>{{cite news
column28: title=Seamus Coleman is Toffees' player of the season while Ross Barkley wins best goal for Man City strike at Everton awards

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: On 29 July 2014, Barkley signed a new contract with Everton, keeping him at the club until 2018.<ref>{{cite news
column9: url-status=dead }}</ref> Before the start of the 2014–15 season he suffered an injury to his [[medial collateral ligament]],<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Roberto Martínez: Ross Barkley may make Everton return in eight weeks
column15: location=London}}</ref> and did not play until 18 October 2014, setting up [[Romelu Lukaku]]'s goal in a 3–0 home league win over [[Aston Villa F.C.
column16: Aston Villa]]. He scored his first goal of the season in a 3–1 win over Queens Park Rangers on 15 December.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30373609\"Everton 3–1 QPR\"]. BBC Sport. 15 December 2014. Retrieved 17 March 2015.</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Barkley started the 2015–16 season with goals in Everton's first two league matches.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33744642\"Everton 2–2 Watford\"]. BBC Sport. 8 August 2015. Retrieved 9 August 2015.</ref>

column6: title=Bluetooth Smart or Version 4.0+ of the Bluetooth specification
column8: wireless personal area network]] technology designed and marketed by the [[Bluetooth Special Interest Group]] (Bluetooth SIG) aimed at novel applications in the healthcare, [[Physical fitness
column16: df=dmy-all }}</ref> security, and home entertainment industries.<ref>{{cite web
column21: website=bluetooth.com}}</ref>  It is independent of [[Bluetooth BR/EDR]] and has no compatibility, but BR/EDR and LE can coexist. The original specification was developed by Nokia in 2006 under the name Wibree<ref>{{Cite web
column23: title=Is Wibree going to rival Bluetooth?
column27: access-date=2020-04-10}}</ref>, which was integrated into Bluetooth 4.0 in December 2009 as Bluetooth Low Energy.

Jasper, Indiana}}: Classic Bluetooth]], Bluetooth Low Energy is intended to provide considerably reduced power consumption and cost while maintaining a [[#Radio_interface
column3: similar communication range]]. Mobile operating systems including [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)
column5: BlackBerry]], as well as [[macOS]], [[Linux]], [[Windows 8]] and [[Windows 10]], natively support Bluetooth Low Energy.

Jasper, Indiana}}: Bluetooth 4.0 specification]] permits devices to implement either or both of the LE and BR/EDR systems.

* Bluetooth Smart indicates a low energy-only device which requires either a Smart Ready or another [[Smart device]] in order to function.

Jasper, Indiana}}: Nokia]] determined various scenarios that contemporary wireless technologies did not address.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Nokia's Wibree and the Wireless Zoo}}</ref> The company began developing a wireless technology adapted from the Bluetooth standard which would provide lower power usage and cost while minimizing its differences from Bluetooth technology. The results were published in 2004 using the name Bluetooth Low End Extension.<ref>{{cite conference
column19: conference=2004 IEEE Radio and Wireless Conference 19–22 September 2004

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The technology was marketed as Bluetooth Smart and integration into version 4.0 of the Core Specification was completed in early 2010.<ref>{{cite web

column16: accessdate=2014-02-09}}</ref> A number of other manufacturers released Bluetooth Low Energy Ready devices in 2012.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The Bluetooth SIG officially unveiled Bluetooth 5 on 16 June 2016 during a media event in London. One change on the marketing side is that the point number was dropped, so it now just called Bluetooth 5 (and not Bluetooth 5.0 or 5.0 LE like for Bluetooth 4.0). This decision was made to \"simplifying marketing, and communicating user benefits more effectively\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Bluetooth 5 Promises Four times the Range, Twice the Speed of Bluetooth 4.0 LE Transmissions
column6: date=10 June 2016}}</ref> On the technical side, Bluetooth 5 will quadruple the range by using increased transmit power or coded physical layer, double the speed by using optional half of the symbol time compared to Bluetooth 4.x, and provide an eight-fold increase in data broadcasting capacity by increasing the advertising data length{{clarify
column7: date=May 2017}} of low energy Bluetooth transmissions compared to Bluetooth 4.x, which could be important for [[Internet of things
column8: IoT]] applications where nodes are connected throughout a whole house.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Bluetooth® 5 Quadruples Range, Doubles Speed, Increases Data Broadcasting Capacity by 800% {{!}} Bluetooth Technology Website

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The Bluetooth SIG released Mesh Profile and Mesh Model specifications officially on 18 July 2017. [[Bluetooth mesh networking
Jasper, Indiana}}: Mesh specification]] enables using Bluetooth Low Energy for many-to-many device communications for home automation, sensor networks and other applications.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Bluetooth SIG Announces Mesh Networking Capability {{!}} Bluetooth Technology Website

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Borrowing from the original Bluetooth specification, the Bluetooth SIG defines several [[Bluetooth profile
Jasper, Indiana}}: profiles]] — specifications for how a device works in a particular application — for low energy devices. Manufacturers are expected to implement the appropriate specifications for their device in order to ensure compatibility. A device may contain implementations of multiple profiles.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The majority of current low energy application profiles are based on the Generic Attribute Profile (GATT), a general specification for sending and receiving short pieces of data, known as attributes, over a low energy link.<ref>Bluetooth SIG [https://www.bluetooth.org/en-us/specification/adopted-specifications Adopted specifications]</ref> The [[Bluetooth mesh]] profile is an exception to this rule, being based on the General Access Profile (GAP).<ref>{{cite web

Bluetooth mesh profiles use Bluetooth Low Energy to communicate with other Bluetooth Low Energy devices in the network. Each device can pass the information forward to other Bluetooth Low Energy devices creating a \"mesh\" effect. For example, switching off an entire building of lights from a single smartphone.<ref>{{cite web
* MESH (Mesh Profile) — for base mesh networking.

Jasper, Indiana}}: Mesh models]]) — for application layer definitions. Term \"model\" is used in mesh specifications instead of \"profile\" to avoid ambiguities.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: There are many profiles for Bluetooth Low Energy devices in healthcare applications. [[The Continua Health Alliance]] consortium promotes these in cooperation with the Bluetooth SIG.
* BLP (Blood Pressure Profile) — for blood pressure measurement.
* HTP (Health Thermometer Profile) — for medical temperature measurement devices.
Profiles for sporting and fitness accessories include:
* CSCP (Cycling Speed and Cadence Profile) — for sensors attached to a [[bicycle]] or [[exercise bike]] to measure [[Cadence (cycling)
* HRP (Heart Rate Profile) — for devices which measure [[heart rate]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: * FMP — the \"find me\" profile — allows one device to issue an alert on a second misplaced device.<ref>{{cite web

* PXP — the proximity profile — allows a proximity monitor to detect whether a proximity reporter is within a close range. Physical proximity can be estimated using the radio receiver's [[RSSI]] value, although this does not have absolute calibration of distances. Typically, an alarm may be sounded when the distance between the devices exceeds a set threshold.
* The phone alert status profile and alert notification profile allow a client device to receive notifications such as incoming call alerts from another device.
* The time profile allows current time and [[time zone]] information on a client device to be set from a server device, such as between a wristwatch and a mobile phone's [[Network Time Protocol
* The Battery Service exposes the Battery State and Battery Level of a single battery or set of batteries in a device.

Announced in January 2020, LE Audio will allow the protocol to carry sound and add features such as one set of headphones connecting to multiple audio sources or multiple headphones connecting to one source<ref>{{Cite news

Current mobile devices are commonly released with hardware and software support for both classic Bluetooth and the Bluetooth Low Energy.

column7: quote=As the MGMT interface is the only one to support the new Bluetooth Low Energy devices, BlueZ developers decided to drop support for the old interface once MGMT was completed. As a result, you need to be running Linux Kernel 3.4 or newer to use BlueZ 5.}}</ref>

column3: title=Wireless Protocols - WiFi, Bluetooth, BT, BTLE, GPS, GPRS, 6loWPAN, Zigbee, RoweBots Bluetooth Stack - RoweBots

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth Low Energy technology operates in the same spectrum range (the 2.400–2.4835 GHz [[ISM band]]) as classic Bluetooth technology, but uses a different set of channels. Instead of the classic Bluetooth seventy-nine 1-MHz channels, Bluetooth Low Energy has forty 2-MHz channels. Within a channel, data is transmitted using [[GFSK
Jasper, Indiana}}: Gaussian frequency shift modulation]], similar to classic Bluetooth's Basic Rate scheme. The bit rate is 1 Mbit/s (with an option of 2 Mbit/s in Bluetooth 5), and the maximum transmit power is 10 mW (100 mW in Bluetooth 5). Further details are given in Volume 6 Part A (Physical Layer Specification) of the [https://www.bluetooth.org/docman/handlers/downloaddoc.ashx?doc_id=229737 Bluetooth Core Specification V4.0].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth Low Energy uses [[frequency hopping]] to counteract narrowband interference problems. Classic Bluetooth also uses frequency hopping but the details are different; as a result, while both [[Federal Communications Commission
Jasper, Indiana}}: FCC]] and [[ETSI]] classify Bluetooth technology as an [[FHSS]] scheme, Bluetooth Low Energy is classified as a system using digital modulation techniques or a [[direct-sequence spread spectrum]].<ref>Bluetooth Special Interest Group [https://www.bluetooth.org/docman/handlers/downloaddoc.ashx?doc_id=237781 \"Bluetooth Low Energy Regulatory Aspects\"], April 2011</ref>

column4: title=Bluetooth Low Energy Technology - Technical Information

Jasper, Indiana}}: Mobile phones, gaming, headsets, stereo audio streaming, smart homes, wearables, automotive, PCs, security, proximity, healthcare, sports & fitness, etc.
Mobile phones, gaming, smart homes, wearables, automotive, PCs, security, proximity, healthcare, sports & fitness, Industrial, etc.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: More technical details may be obtained from official specification as published by the Bluetooth SIG. Note that power consumption is not part of the Bluetooth specification.

BLE devices are detected through a procedure based on broadcasting advertising packets. This is done using 3 separate channels (frequencies), in order to reduce interference. The advertising device sends a packet on at least one of these three channels, with a repetition period called the advertising interval. For reducing the chance of multiple consecutive collisions, a random delay of up to 10 milliseconds is added to each advertising interval. The scanner listens to the channel for a duration called the scan window, which is periodically repeated every scan interval.

The discovery latency is therefore determined by a probabilistic process and depends on the three parameters (viz., the advertising interval, the scan interval and the scan window). The discovery scheme of BLE adopts a periodic-interval based technique, for which upper bounds on the discovery latency can be inferred for most parametrizations. While the discovery latencies of BLE can be approximated by models<ref>{{Cite journal
Jasper, Indiana}}: title=PI-LatencyComp - Neighbor Discovery in BLE-Like protocols
column11: first1=Philipp H.}}</ref> for purely periodic interval-based protocols, the random delay added to each advertising interval and the three-channel discovery can cause deviations from these predictions, or potentially lead to unbounded latencies for certain parametrizations.<ref>{{Cite journal
column21: title=Neighbor Discovery Latency in BLE-Like Protocols

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth LE comes with very low, and in many cases broken security. BTLE or Bluetooth Smart, is a new modulation mode and link layer packet format targeting low powered devices and is found in recent high-end smart phones, sports devices, sensors, and will soon appear in many medical devices. Unfortunately the security implementation is broken with the encryption of any Bluetooth LE Energy link easily being rendered useless. This flaw in security can allow any device nearby to eavesdrop on Bluetooth Low Energy conversations. This includes packets being intercepted and reassembled into connection streams, as well as injection attacks.<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=A Robust Algorithm for Sniffing BLE Long-Lived Connections in Real-Time
column12: doi=10.1109/GLOBECOM38437.2019.9014318}}</ref><!--Paragraph is section simply recopied on 13 Apr 20 after deletion in 2014, needs updating and expanding, see Talk. A detailed reference which is useful, though considered not to be WP_reliable (hence section deletion): <ref>[http://0b4af6cdc2f0c5998459-c0245c5c937c5dedcca3f1764ecc9b2f.r43.cf2.rackcdn.cm/12053-woot13-ryan.pdf Bluetooth: With Low Energy comes Low Security]</ref>-->

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth LE has been suggested as the basis of an app for tracing contacts of people during the [[Covid pandemic]] of 2020, silently tracking other phones which come within BT LE range of a person's phone, allowing those who have been in sustained proximity with a possibly infected person to be notified without identifying the person. However, a draft government memo said that ministers might be given the ability to identify people from their mobile phones, which has been criticised as a potential security breach.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=NHS coronavirus app: memo discussed giving ministers power to 'de-anonymise' users

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: All Bluetooth Low Energy devices use the Generic Attribute Profile (GATT). The [[application programming interface]] offered by a Bluetooth Low Energy aware operating system will typically be based around GATT concepts.<ref>See for example Apple's [https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/CoreBluetooth/Reference/CoreBluetooth_Framework/_index.html Core Bluetooth] framework</ref> GATT has the following terminology:
:A device that initiates GATT commands and requests, and accepts responses, for example, a computer or smartphone.
:A device that receives GATT commands and requests, and returns responses, for example, a temperature sensor.
:A data value transferred between client and server, for example, the current battery voltage.

:A collection of related characteristics, which operate together to perform a particular function. For instance, the ''Health Thermometer'' service includes characteristics for a temperature measurement value, and a time interval between measurements.

:A descriptor provides additional information about a characteristic. For instance, a temperature value characteristic may have an indication of its units (e.g. Celsius), and the maximum and minimum values which the sensor can measure. Descriptors are optional – each characteristic can have any number of descriptors.

Some service and characteristic values are used for administrative purposes – for instance, the model name and serial number can be read as standard characteristics within the ''Generic Access'' service. Services may also include other services as sub-functions; the main functions of the device are so-called ''primary'' services, and the auxiliary functions they refer to are ''secondary'' services.
Services, characteristics, and descriptors are collectively referred to as ''attributes'', and identified by [[Universally unique identifier
Jasper, Indiana}}: UUID]]s. Any implementer may pick a random or pseudorandom UUID for [[Proprietary format
column3: proprietary]] uses, but the Bluetooth SIG have reserved a range of UUIDs (of the form ''{{not a typo
column4: xxxxxxxx-0000-1000-8000-00805F9B34FB}}'' <ref>See sec 2.5.1 of the ''Bluetooth 4.0 Core Specification''</ref>) for standard attributes. For efficiency, these identifiers are represented as 16-bit or 32-bit values in the protocol, rather than the 128 bits required for a full UUID. For example, the ''Device Information'' service has the short code 0x180A, rather than {{not a typo
column5: 0000180A-0000-1000-}}... . The full list is kept in the [https://www.bluetooth.com/specifications/gatt/services/ Bluetooth Assigned Numbers] document online.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The GATT protocol provides a number of commands for the client to discover information about the server. These include:
* Discover UUIDs for all primary services
* Find a service with a given UUID
* Find secondary services for a given primary service
* Discover all characteristics for a given service
* Find characteristics matching a given UUID
* Read all descriptors for a particular characteristic
Commands are also provided to ''read'' (data transfer from server to client) and ''write'' (from client to server) the values of characteristics:
* A value may be read either by specifying the characteristic's UUID, or by a ''handle'' value (which is returned by the information discovery commands above).
* Write operations always identify the characteristic by handle, but have a choice of whether or not a response from the server is required.
* 'Long read' and 'Long write' operations can be used when the length of the characteristic's data exceeds the [[Maximum transmission unit

Finally, GATT offers ''notifications'' and ''indications''. The client may request a notification for a particular characteristic from the server. The server can then send the value to the client whenever it becomes available. For instance, a temperature sensor server may notify its client every time it takes a measurement. This avoids the need for the client to [[Polling (computer science)
Jasper, Indiana}}: poll]] the server, which would require the server's radio circuitry to be constantly operational.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: An ''indication'' is similar to a notification, except that it requires a response from the client, as confirmation that it has received the message.

column5: Bluetooth Low Energy chipset power consumption profiles with different configuration parameters, as per The Hitchhikers Guide to iBeacon Hardware by Aislelabs.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Hitchhikers Guide to iBeacon Hardware: A Comprehensive Report by Aislelabs

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth Low Energy is designed to enable devices to have very low power consumption. Several chipmakers including [[Cambridge Silicon Radio]], [[Dialog Semiconductor]], [[Nordic Semiconductor]], [[STMicroelectronics]], [[Cypress Semiconductor]], [[Silicon Labs]] and [[Texas Instruments]] had introduced Bluetooth Low Energy optimized chipsets by 2014. Devices with peripheral and central roles have different power requirements. A study by beacon software company [[Aislelabs]] reported that peripherals such as proximity beacons usually function for 1–2 years powered by a 1,000mAh coin cell battery.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How to find the best beacon hardware for everything from stores to cities
column6: accessdate=2014-10-11}}</ref> This is possible because of the power efficiency of Bluetooth Low Energy protocol, which only transmits small packets as compared to Bluetooth Classic which is also suitable for audio and high bandwidth data.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In contrast, a continuous scan for the same beacons in central role can consume 1,000 mAh in a few hours. Android and iOS devices also have very different battery impact depending on type of scans and the number of Bluetooth Low Energy devices in the vicinity.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=In terms of battery life, Android devices are more optimized for iBeacons than iPhones
column6: accessdate=2014-10-07}}</ref> With newer chipsets and advances in software, by 2014 both Android and iOS phones had negligible power consumption in real-life Bluetooth Low Energy use.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=iBeacon Battery Drain on Apple vs Android: A Technical Report

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth 5 has introduced a new transmission mode with a doubled [[symbol rate]]. Bluetooth LE has been traditionally transmitting 1 bit per symbol so that theoretically the data rate doubles as well. However the new mode doubles the [[Bandwidth (signal processing)
Jasper, Indiana}}: bandwidth]] from about 1 MHz to about 2 MHz which makes for more interferences on the edge regions. The partitioning of the ISM frequency band has not changed being still 40 channels spaced at a distance of 2 MHz.<ref name=edn2017>{{cite web
column4: title=Bluetooth 5: More speeds, more range, new RF tests
column7: publisher=EDN Network}}</ref> This is an essential differences over Bluetooth 2 EDR which did also double the data rate but it is doing that by employing a π/4-DQPSK or 8-DPSK [[phase modulation]] on a 1 MhZ channel while Bluetooth 5 continues to use just frequency shift keying.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The traditional transmission of 1 Mbit in the Bluetooth Basic Rate was renamed 1M PHY in Bluetooth 5. The new mode at a doubled symbol speed was introduced as the 2M PHY. In Bluetooth Low Energy every transmission starts on the 1M PHY leaving it to the application to initiate a switch to the 2M PHY. In that case both sender and receiver will switch to the 2M PHY for transmissions. This is designed to facilitate firmware updates where the application can switch back to a traditional 1M PHY in case of errors. In reality the target device should be close to the programming station (at a few meters).

Bluetooth 5 has introduced two new modes with lower data rate. The symbol rate of the new \"Coded PHY\" is the same as the Base Rate 1M PHY but in mode S=2 there are two symbols transmitted per data bit. In mode S=2 only a simple Pattern Mapping P=1 is used which simply produces the same stuffing bit for each input data bit. In mode S=8 there are eight symbols per data bit with a Pattern Mapping P=4 producing contrasting symbol sequences - a 0 bit is encoded as binary 0011 and a 1 bit is encoded as binary 1100.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=What is Bluetooth 5? Learn about the Bit Paths Behind the New BLE Standard
column4: author=Mark Hughes}}</ref> In mode S=2 using P=1 the range doubles approximately, while in mode S=8 using P=4 it does quadruple.<ref>{{Cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The \"LE Coded\" transmissions have not only changed the error correction scheme but it uses a fundamentally new package format. Each \"LE Coded\" burst consists of three blocks. The switch block (\"extended preamble\") is transmitted on the LE 1M PHY but it does only consist of 10 times a binaryr '00111100' pattern. These 80 bits are not FEC encoded as usual but they are sent directly to the radio channel. It is followed by a header block (\"FEC Block 1\") which is always transmitted in S=8 mode. The header block does only contain the destination address (\"Access Address\" / 32 bit) and an encoding flag (\"Coding Indicator\" / 2 Bit). The Coding Indicator defines the Pattern Mapping used for the following payload block (\"FEC Block 2\") where S=2 is possible.<ref name=edn2018>{{cite web

The new package format of Bluetooth 5 allows to transmit from 2 up to 256 bytes as the payload in a single burst. This is a lot more than the maximum of 31 bytes in Bluetooth 4. Along with reach measurements this should allow for localisation functions. As a whole the quadrupled range - at the same transmission power - is achieved at the expense of a lower data being at an eight with 125 kBit. The old transmission package format, as it continues to be used in the 1M PHY and 2M PHY modes, has been named \"Uncoded\" in Bluetooth 5. The intermediate \"LE Coded\" S=2 mode allows for a  500 kBit data rate in the payload which is both beneficial for shorter latencies as well lower power consumption as the burst time itself is shorter.

* low power requirements, operating for \"months or years\" on a [[button cell]]
* compatibility with a large [[installed base]] of mobile phones, tablets and computers

Jasper, Indiana}}: Nokia]] determined various scenarios that contemporary wireless technologies did not address.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Nokia's Wibree and the Wireless Zoo}}</ref> The company began developing a wireless technology adapted from the Bluetooth standard which would provide lower power usage and cost while minimizing its differences from Bluetooth technology. The results were published in 2004 using the name Bluetooth Low End Extension.<ref>{{cite conference
column19: conference=2004 IEEE Radio and Wireless Conference 19–22 September 2004

column12: access-date=2016-08-18}}</ref>}} the technology was released to the public in October 2006 with the brand name Wibree.<ref>{{cite news
column17: access-date=2018-04-27}}</ref> After negotiations with Bluetooth SIG members, an agreement was reached in June 2007 to include Wibree in a future Bluetooth specification as a Bluetooth ultra low power technology.<ref>{{cite press release
column19: title=Wibree forum merges with Bluetooth SIG

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The technology was marketed as Bluetooth Smart and integration into version 4.0 of the Core Specification was completed in early 2010.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Bluetooth SIG unveils Smart Marks, explains v4.0 compatibility with unnecessary complexity
column9: accessdate=2018-04-17}}</ref> The first smartphone to implement the 4.0 specification was the [[iPhone 4S]], released in October 2011.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=iPhone 4S claims title of first Bluetooth 4.0 smartphone, ready to stream data from your cat
column16: accessdate=2014-02-09}}</ref> A number of other manufacturers released Bluetooth Low Energy Ready devices in 2012.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The Bluetooth SIG officially unveiled Bluetooth 5 on 16 June 2016 during a media event in London. One change on the marketing side is that the point number was dropped, so it now just called Bluetooth 5 (and not Bluetooth 5.0 or 5.0 LE like for Bluetooth 4.0). This decision was made to \"simplifying marketing, and communicating user benefits more effectively\".<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Bluetooth 5 Promises Four times the Range, Twice the Speed of Bluetooth 4.0 LE Transmissions
column6: date=10 June 2016}}</ref> On the technical side, Bluetooth 5 will quadruple the range by using increased transmit power or coded physical layer, double the speed by using optional half of the symbol time compared to Bluetooth 4.x, and provide an eight-fold increase in data broadcasting capacity by increasing the advertising data length{{clarify
column7: date=May 2017}} of low energy Bluetooth transmissions compared to Bluetooth 4.x, which could be important for [[Internet of things
column8: IoT]] applications where nodes are connected throughout a whole house.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Bluetooth® 5 Quadruples Range, Doubles Speed, Increases Data Broadcasting Capacity by 800% {{!}} Bluetooth Technology Website

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The Bluetooth SIG released Mesh Profile and Mesh Model specifications officially on 18 July 2017. [[Bluetooth mesh networking
Jasper, Indiana}}: Mesh specification]] enables using Bluetooth Low Energy for many-to-many device communications for home automation, sensor networks and other applications.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Bluetooth SIG Announces Mesh Networking Capability {{!}} Bluetooth Technology Website

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Borrowing from the original Bluetooth specification, the Bluetooth SIG defines several [[Bluetooth profile
Jasper, Indiana}}: profiles]] — specifications for how a device works in a particular application — for low energy devices. Manufacturers are expected to implement the appropriate specifications for their device in order to ensure compatibility. A device may contain implementations of multiple profiles.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The majority of current low energy application profiles are based on the Generic Attribute Profile (GATT), a general specification for sending and receiving short pieces of data, known as attributes, over a low energy link.<ref>Bluetooth SIG [https://www.bluetooth.org/en-us/specification/adopted-specifications Adopted specifications]</ref> The [[Bluetooth mesh]] profile is an exception to this rule, being based on the General Access Profile (GAP).<ref>{{cite web

Bluetooth mesh profiles use Bluetooth Low Energy to communicate with other Bluetooth Low Energy devices in the network. Each device can pass the information forward to other Bluetooth Low Energy devices creating a \"mesh\" effect. For example, switching off an entire building of lights from a single smartphone.<ref>{{cite web
* MESH (Mesh Profile) — for base mesh networking.

Jasper, Indiana}}: Mesh models]]) — for application layer definitions. Term \"model\" is used in mesh specifications instead of \"profile\" to avoid ambiguities.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: There are many profiles for Bluetooth Low Energy devices in healthcare applications. [[The Continua Health Alliance]] consortium promotes these in cooperation with the Bluetooth SIG.
* BLP (Blood Pressure Profile) — for blood pressure measurement.
* HTP (Health Thermometer Profile) — for medical temperature measurement devices.
Profiles for sporting and fitness accessories include:
* CSCP (Cycling Speed and Cadence Profile) — for sensors attached to a [[bicycle]] or [[exercise bike]] to measure [[Cadence (cycling)
* HRP (Heart Rate Profile) — for devices which measure [[heart rate]]

Jasper, Indiana}}: HID]] over GATT Profile) allowing Bluetooth LE-enabled Wireless mice, keyboards and other devices offering long-lasting battery life.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: * FMP — the \"find me\" profile — allows one device to issue an alert on a second misplaced device.<ref>{{cite web

* PXP — the proximity profile — allows a proximity monitor to detect whether a proximity reporter is within a close range. Physical proximity can be estimated using the radio receiver's [[RSSI]] value, although this does not have absolute calibration of distances. Typically, an alarm may be sounded when the distance between the devices exceeds a set threshold.
* The phone alert status profile and alert notification profile allow a client device to receive notifications such as incoming call alerts from another device.
* The time profile allows current time and [[time zone]] information on a client device to be set from a server device, such as between a wristwatch and a mobile phone's [[Network Time Protocol
* The Battery Service exposes the Battery State and Battery Level of a single battery or set of batteries in a device.

Announced in January 2020, LE Audio will allow the protocol to carry sound and add features such as one set of headphones connecting to multiple audio sources or multiple headphones connecting to one source<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=The New Version of Bluetooth Is Here to Fix Your Headphones
column9: title=Bluetooth SIG Announces 'LE Audio' With Audio Sharing, Lower Data Consumption, Hearing Aid Support and More
column14: access-date=2020-02-03}}</ref> it will also add support for hearing aids<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=Hearing Aid Audio Support Using Bluetooth LE

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Starting in late 2009, Bluetooth Low Energy [[integrated circuits]] were announced by a number of manufacturers. These ICs commonly use [[software radio]] so updates to the specification can be accommodated through a [[firmware]] upgrade.
Current mobile devices are commonly released with hardware and software support for both classic Bluetooth and the Bluetooth Low Energy.

column7: quote=As the MGMT interface is the only one to support the new Bluetooth Low Energy devices, BlueZ developers decided to drop support for the old interface once MGMT was completed. As a result, you need to be running Linux Kernel 3.4 or newer to use BlueZ 5.}}</ref>

column3: title=Wireless Protocols - WiFi, Bluetooth, BT, BTLE, GPS, GPRS, 6loWPAN, Zigbee, RoweBots Bluetooth Stack - RoweBots

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth Low Energy technology operates in the same spectrum range (the 2.400–2.4835 GHz [[ISM band]]) as classic Bluetooth technology, but uses a different set of channels. Instead of the classic Bluetooth seventy-nine 1-MHz channels, Bluetooth Low Energy has forty 2-MHz channels. Within a channel, data is transmitted using [[GFSK
Jasper, Indiana}}: Gaussian frequency shift modulation]], similar to classic Bluetooth's Basic Rate scheme. The bit rate is 1 Mbit/s (with an option of 2 Mbit/s in Bluetooth 5), and the maximum transmit power is 10 mW (100 mW in Bluetooth 5). Further details are given in Volume 6 Part A (Physical Layer Specification) of the [https://www.bluetooth.org/docman/handlers/downloaddoc.ashx?doc_id=229737 Bluetooth Core Specification V4.0].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth Low Energy uses [[frequency hopping]] to counteract narrowband interference problems. Classic Bluetooth also uses frequency hopping but the details are different; as a result, while both [[Federal Communications Commission
Jasper, Indiana}}: FCC]] and [[ETSI]] classify Bluetooth technology as an [[FHSS]] scheme, Bluetooth Low Energy is classified as a system using digital modulation techniques or a [[direct-sequence spread spectrum]].<ref>Bluetooth Special Interest Group [https://www.bluetooth.org/docman/handlers/downloaddoc.ashx?doc_id=237781 \"Bluetooth Low Energy Regulatory Aspects\"], April 2011</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: ! Bluetooth Basic Rate/Enhanced Data Rate technology

column4: title=Bluetooth Low Energy Technology - Technical Information

Jasper, Indiana}}: Mobile phones, gaming, headsets, stereo audio streaming, smart homes, wearables, automotive, PCs, security, proximity, healthcare, sports & fitness, etc.
Mobile phones, gaming, smart homes, wearables, automotive, PCs, security, proximity, healthcare, sports & fitness, Industrial, etc.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: More technical details may be obtained from official specification as published by the Bluetooth SIG. Note that power consumption is not part of the Bluetooth specification.

BLE devices are detected through a procedure based on broadcasting advertising packets. This is done using 3 separate channels (frequencies), in order to reduce interference. The advertising device sends a packet on at least one of these three channels, with a repetition period called the advertising interval. For reducing the chance of multiple consecutive collisions, a random delay of up to 10 milliseconds is added to each advertising interval. The scanner listens to the channel for a duration called the scan window, which is periodically repeated every scan interval.

The discovery latency is therefore determined by a probabilistic process and depends on the three parameters (viz., the advertising interval, the scan interval and the scan window). The discovery scheme of BLE adopts a periodic-interval based technique, for which upper bounds on the discovery latency can be inferred for most parametrizations. While the discovery latencies of BLE can be approximated by models<ref>{{Cite journal
Jasper, Indiana}}: title=PI-LatencyComp - Neighbor Discovery in BLE-Like protocols
column11: first1=Philipp H.}}</ref> for purely periodic interval-based protocols, the random delay added to each advertising interval and the three-channel discovery can cause deviations from these predictions, or potentially lead to unbounded latencies for certain parametrizations.<ref>{{Cite journal
column21: title=Neighbor Discovery Latency in BLE-Like Protocols

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth LE comes with very low, and in many cases broken security. BTLE or Bluetooth Smart, is a new modulation mode and link layer packet format targeting low powered devices and is found in recent high-end smart phones, sports devices, sensors, and will soon appear in many medical devices. Unfortunately the security implementation is broken with the encryption of any Bluetooth LE Energy link easily being rendered useless. This flaw in security can allow any device nearby to eavesdrop on Bluetooth Low Energy conversations. This includes packets being intercepted and reassembled into connection streams, as well as injection attacks.<ref>{{cite journal
column8: title=A Robust Algorithm for Sniffing BLE Long-Lived Connections in Real-Time
column12: doi=10.1109/GLOBECOM38437.2019.9014318}}</ref><!--Paragraph is section simply recopied on 13 Apr 20 after deletion in 2014, needs updating and expanding, see Talk. A detailed reference which is useful, though considered not to be WP_reliable (hence section deletion): <ref>[http://0b4af6cdc2f0c5998459-c0245c5c937c5dedcca3f1764ecc9b2f.r43.cf2.rackcdn.cm/12053-woot13-ryan.pdf Bluetooth: With Low Energy comes Low Security]</ref>-->

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth LE has been suggested as the basis of an app for tracing contacts of people during the [[Covid pandemic]] of 2020, silently tracking other phones which come within BT LE range of a person's phone, allowing those who have been in sustained proximity with a possibly infected person to be notified without identifying the person. However, a draft government memo said that ministers might be given the ability to identify people from their mobile phones, which has been criticised as a potential security breach.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=NHS coronavirus app: memo discussed giving ministers power to 'de-anonymise' users

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: All Bluetooth Low Energy devices use the Generic Attribute Profile (GATT). The [[application programming interface]] offered by a Bluetooth Low Energy aware operating system will typically be based around GATT concepts.<ref>See for example Apple's [https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/CoreBluetooth/Reference/CoreBluetooth_Framework/_index.html Core Bluetooth] framework</ref> GATT has the following terminology:
:A device that initiates GATT commands and requests, and accepts responses, for example, a computer or smartphone.
:A device that receives GATT commands and requests, and returns responses, for example, a temperature sensor.
:A data value transferred between client and server, for example, the current battery voltage.

:A collection of related characteristics, which operate together to perform a particular function. For instance, the ''Health Thermometer'' service includes characteristics for a temperature measurement value, and a time interval between measurements.

:A descriptor provides additional information about a characteristic. For instance, a temperature value characteristic may have an indication of its units (e.g. Celsius), and the maximum and minimum values which the sensor can measure. Descriptors are optional – each characteristic can have any number of descriptors.

Some service and characteristic values are used for administrative purposes – for instance, the model name and serial number can be read as standard characteristics within the ''Generic Access'' service. Services may also include other services as sub-functions; the main functions of the device are so-called ''primary'' services, and the auxiliary functions they refer to are ''secondary'' services.
Services, characteristics, and descriptors are collectively referred to as ''attributes'', and identified by [[Universally unique identifier
Jasper, Indiana}}: UUID]]s. Any implementer may pick a random or pseudorandom UUID for [[Proprietary format
column3: proprietary]] uses, but the Bluetooth SIG have reserved a range of UUIDs (of the form ''{{not a typo
column4: xxxxxxxx-0000-1000-8000-00805F9B34FB}}'' <ref>See sec 2.5.1 of the ''Bluetooth 4.0 Core Specification''</ref>) for standard attributes. For efficiency, these identifiers are represented as 16-bit or 32-bit values in the protocol, rather than the 128 bits required for a full UUID. For example, the ''Device Information'' service has the short code 0x180A, rather than {{not a typo
column5: 0000180A-0000-1000-}}... . The full list is kept in the [https://www.bluetooth.com/specifications/gatt/services/ Bluetooth Assigned Numbers] document online.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The GATT protocol provides a number of commands for the client to discover information about the server. These include:
* Discover UUIDs for all primary services
* Find a service with a given UUID
* Find secondary services for a given primary service
* Discover all characteristics for a given service
* Find characteristics matching a given UUID
* Read all descriptors for a particular characteristic
Commands are also provided to ''read'' (data transfer from server to client) and ''write'' (from client to server) the values of characteristics:
* A value may be read either by specifying the characteristic's UUID, or by a ''handle'' value (which is returned by the information discovery commands above).
* Write operations always identify the characteristic by handle, but have a choice of whether or not a response from the server is required.
* 'Long read' and 'Long write' operations can be used when the length of the characteristic's data exceeds the [[Maximum transmission unit

Finally, GATT offers ''notifications'' and ''indications''. The client may request a notification for a particular characteristic from the server. The server can then send the value to the client whenever it becomes available. For instance, a temperature sensor server may notify its client every time it takes a measurement. This avoids the need for the client to [[Polling (computer science)
Jasper, Indiana}}: poll]] the server, which would require the server's radio circuitry to be constantly operational.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: An ''indication'' is similar to a notification, except that it requires a response from the client, as confirmation that it has received the message.

column5: Bluetooth Low Energy chipset power consumption profiles with different configuration parameters, as per The Hitchhikers Guide to iBeacon Hardware by Aislelabs.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Hitchhikers Guide to iBeacon Hardware: A Comprehensive Report by Aislelabs

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth Low Energy is designed to enable devices to have very low power consumption. Several chipmakers including [[Cambridge Silicon Radio]], [[Dialog Semiconductor]], [[Nordic Semiconductor]], [[STMicroelectronics]], [[Cypress Semiconductor]], [[Silicon Labs]] and [[Texas Instruments]] had introduced Bluetooth Low Energy optimized chipsets by 2014. Devices with peripheral and central roles have different power requirements. A study by beacon software company [[Aislelabs]] reported that peripherals such as proximity beacons usually function for 1–2 years powered by a 1,000mAh coin cell battery.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How to find the best beacon hardware for everything from stores to cities
column6: accessdate=2014-10-11}}</ref> This is possible because of the power efficiency of Bluetooth Low Energy protocol, which only transmits small packets as compared to Bluetooth Classic which is also suitable for audio and high bandwidth data.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In contrast, a continuous scan for the same beacons in central role can consume 1,000 mAh in a few hours. Android and iOS devices also have very different battery impact depending on type of scans and the number of Bluetooth Low Energy devices in the vicinity.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=In terms of battery life, Android devices are more optimized for iBeacons than iPhones
column6: accessdate=2014-10-07}}</ref> With newer chipsets and advances in software, by 2014 both Android and iOS phones had negligible power consumption in real-life Bluetooth Low Energy use.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=iBeacon Battery Drain on Apple vs Android: A Technical Report

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Bluetooth 5 has introduced a new transmission mode with a doubled [[symbol rate]]. Bluetooth LE has been traditionally transmitting 1 bit per symbol so that theoretically the data rate doubles as well. However the new mode doubles the [[Bandwidth (signal processing)
Jasper, Indiana}}: bandwidth]] from about 1 MHz to about 2 MHz which makes for more interferences on the edge regions. The partitioning of the ISM frequency band has not changed being still 40 channels spaced at a distance of 2 MHz.<ref name=edn2017>{{cite web
column4: title=Bluetooth 5: More speeds, more range, new RF tests
column7: publisher=EDN Network}}</ref> This is an essential differences over Bluetooth 2 EDR which did also double the data rate but it is doing that by employing a π/4-DQPSK or 8-DPSK [[phase modulation]] on a 1 MhZ channel while Bluetooth 5 continues to use just frequency shift keying.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The traditional transmission of 1 Mbit in the Bluetooth Basic Rate was renamed 1M PHY in Bluetooth 5. The new mode at a doubled symbol speed was introduced as the 2M PHY. In Bluetooth Low Energy every transmission starts on the 1M PHY leaving it to the application to initiate a switch to the 2M PHY. In that case both sender and receiver will switch to the 2M PHY for transmissions. This is designed to facilitate firmware updates where the application can switch back to a traditional 1M PHY in case of errors. In reality the target device should be close to the programming station (at a few meters).

Bluetooth 5 has introduced two new modes with lower data rate. The symbol rate of the new \"Coded PHY\" is the same as the Base Rate 1M PHY but in mode S=2 there are two symbols transmitted per data bit. In mode S=2 only a simple Pattern Mapping P=1 is used which simply produces the same stuffing bit for each input data bit. In mode S=8 there are eight symbols per data bit with a Pattern Mapping P=4 producing contrasting symbol sequences - a 0 bit is encoded as binary 0011 and a 1 bit is encoded as binary 1100.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=What is Bluetooth 5? Learn about the Bit Paths Behind the New BLE Standard
column4: author=Mark Hughes}}</ref> In mode S=2 using P=1 the range doubles approximately, while in mode S=8 using P=4 it does quadruple.<ref>{{Cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The \"LE Coded\" transmissions have not only changed the error correction scheme but it uses a fundamentally new package format. Each \"LE Coded\" burst consists of three blocks. The switch block (\"extended preamble\") is transmitted on the LE 1M PHY but it does only consist of 10 times a binaryr '00111100' pattern. These 80 bits are not FEC encoded as usual but they are sent directly to the radio channel. It is followed by a header block (\"FEC Block 1\") which is always transmitted in S=8 mode. The header block does only contain the destination address (\"Access Address\" / 32 bit) and an encoding flag (\"Coding Indicator\" / 2 Bit). The Coding Indicator defines the Pattern Mapping used for the following payload block (\"FEC Block 2\") where S=2 is possible.<ref name=edn2018>{{cite web

The new package format of Bluetooth 5 allows to transmit from 2 up to 256 bytes as the payload in a single burst. This is a lot more than the maximum of 31 bytes in Bluetooth 4. Along with reach measurements this should allow for localisation functions. As a whole the quadrupled range - at the same transmission power - is achieved at the expense of a lower data being at an eight with 125 kBit. The old transmission package format, as it continues to be used in the 1M PHY and 2M PHY modes, has been named \"Uncoded\" in Bluetooth 5. The intermediate \"LE Coded\" S=2 mode allows for a  500 kBit data rate in the payload which is both beneficial for shorter latencies as well lower power consumption as the burst time itself is shorter.

Jasper, Indiana}}: Dick Donovan, the pseudonym of the British author

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: * [[List of Major League Baseball annual ERA leaders
'''Richard Edward Donovan''' (December 27, 1927 – January 6, 1997) was an American [[Major League Baseball]] [[pitcher]] who played for the [[Boston Braves (baseball)
Jasper, Indiana}}: Boston Braves]] (1950–1952), [[Detroit Tigers]] (1954), [[Chicago White Sox]] (1955–1960), [[Washington Senators (1961–71)
column3: Washington Senators]] (1961) and [[Cleveland Indians]] (1962–1965). He batted left-handed and threw right-handed, stood {{convert

Jasper, Indiana}}: Boston]] native, Donovan graduated from [[North Quincy High School]] and served in the [[United States Navy]] during and after [[World War II]]. Signed by the hometown Braves, he reached the major leagues in 1950 but was used sporadically over the next several years. While pitching for the minor league [[Atlanta Crackers]], he learned how to throw a [[Slider (baseball)
column3: slider]], and this helped him claim a spot in the White Sox' rotation in 1955. He was an [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game
column4: All-Star]] in his first major league season, winning 15 games with only nine losses. In 1956, he led the [[American League]] (AL) with a 1.155 [[walks plus hits per innings pitched]]. He led the AL with a .727 [[winning percentage]] in 1957, going 16–6, and he won 15 games for the White Sox in 1958. He pitched in the [[1959 World Series]] against the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], losing Game 3 but earning the [[Save (baseball)
column5: save]] in Game 5. Donovan struggled in 1960 and was moved to the [[bullpen]], then got selected in the [[1960 Major League Baseball expansion draft
column6: expansion draft]] by the Senators after the season. He had his best year with the new club in 1961, leading the AL with a 2.40 [[earned run average]] (ERA), though his won-loss record was just 10–10. Traded to the Indians for [[Jimmy Piersall]] after the season, he won 20 games his first year with Cleveland. Donovan pitched three more years for the Indians after that before getting released midway through 1965. Following his baseball career, he sold insurance and held other jobs in the [[Quincy, Massachusetts]] area before dying of cancer in 1997.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan was unusually good at hitting for a pitcher, homering 15 times in his big-league career.

Donovan was the youngest of five children of Jeremiah and Gertrude Donovan. He grew up in Boston and attended [[North Quincy High School]], where he played [[shortstop]] until his senior year, when he switched positions and became a [[pitcher]]. Donovan also pitched for the [[Catholic Youth Organization]]. [[Ken Coleman]], broadcaster for the [[Cleveland Indians]], told the story that once, Donovan was invited to pitch for the [[American Legion]] All-Star team in an [[exhibition game]]. Upon arriving at the park, he was told that he would merely be used in the [[bullpen]]. Protesting that he had been promised more, Donovan left the field and went home. \"To me, this incident typified the makeup of Dick. He still has the determination to do what he thinks is right, and has the wonderful ability to see the humor in a situation,\" Coleman said.<ref name=\"SABR\">{{cite web
column7: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> Donovan's pitching attracted the attention of [[Boston Braves (baseball)
column8: Boston Braves]]' scout Jeff Jones, who signed him after his senior year and proclaimed him \"the fire-ballingest pitcher” he had seen since spotting [[Bob Feller]] pitching in high school. Donovan graduated during [[World War II]], though, and he served three years in the [[United States Navy]] before beginning his professional career in 1947.<ref name=\"SABR\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan's career started far south of his home, with the [[Fort Lauderdale Braves]] of the [[Class C (baseball)
Jasper, Indiana}}: Class C]] [[Florida International League]]. He had a 7–15 [[Win-loss record (pitching)
column3: record]] and a 4.17 [[earned run average]] (ERA) in his first professional season but still got promoted to the [[Class B (baseball)
column4: Class B]] [[Evansville Braves]] of the [[Illinois-Indiana-Iowa League]]. With Evansville in 1948, he had a 12–9 record and a 3.08 ERA.<ref name=\"minors\">{{cite web
column6: title=Dick Donovan Minor Leagues Statistics & History
column8: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> He moved on to the [[Hartford Chiefs]] of the [[Class A (baseball)
column10: Eastern League]] in 1949, posting a 12–6 record and a 2.66 ERA and earning a promotion to the [[Class AAA (baseball)
column12: Milwaukee Brewers]] of the [[American Association (20th Century)
column13: American Association]], the Braves' top farm team, for a couple games.<ref name=\"minors\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: By 1950, Donovan was one of three rookie pitching prospects looking to make it with the [[Boston Braves (baseball)
Jasper, Indiana}}: Boston Braves]], along with [[Norman Roy]] and George Uhle, Jr. The ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]'' wrote, \"The best of the prospects seems to be Roy, who had a great year in 1949 at Milwaukee.\"<ref>{{cite web
column10: page=15}}</ref> Uhle apparently got hurt (he only appeared in four games in the minors that year and never pitched again), but Roy and Donovan both made the Braves out of [[spring training]], Donovan as a starter.<ref name=\"SABR\"/><ref>{{cite web
column14: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> He made his major league debut on April 24, giving up six [[Run (baseball)
column19: innings]] and taking the loss in a 6–4 defeat to the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]].<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Brooklyn Dodgers at Boston Braves Box Score, April 24, 1950
column23: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> Donovan lost his next start, moved to the bullpen, then went to Milwaukee after appearing in two more games.<ref name=\"1950 Donovan\">{{cite web
column27: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> He was called up in June and in September but spent most of the rest of the year in the minors.<ref name=\"1950 Donovan\"/> In 10 games (three starts) his rookie year, Donovan had an 0–2 record, an 8.19 ERA, nine [[strikeout]]s, and 34 [[Walk (baseball)
column31: 3}} innings.<ref name=\"reference\"/> His numbers were not much better at Milwaukee, where in 19 games (10 starts) he had a 3–6 record, a 6.24 ERA, 44 strikeouts, and 33 walks in 75 innings.<ref name=\"minors\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 1951, Donovan started the season with the Braves again but was again moved to the bullpen after two starts.<ref name=\"1951 Donovan\">{{cite web
column5: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> He had a 5.27 ERA (with no record) in eight games with the Braves and did not appear for them after June 5.<ref name=\"1951 Donovan\"/> Spending most of the season with Milwaukee, Donovan had more success with the Brewers in 1951. He had a 7–5 record, a 3.28 ERA, 88 strikeouts, and 59 walks in 129 innings, and he helped the Brewers win the American Association pennant.<ref name=\"SABR\"/><ref name=\"minors\"/> However, he did not pitch for the Braves in September.<ref name=\"1951 Donovan\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Similarly to his previous two years, Donovan started the season with the Braves, then spent most of the year in Milwaukee, with the exception of a brief call-up in late May to early June. In his only two starts, he gave up six runs in one and was pulled from the game in the other after walking the first three hitters.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> He had a 5.54 ERA and an 0–2 record with the Braves. With Milwaukee, he appeared in 16 games (12 starts), posting a 4–6 record, a 4.55 ERA, 36 strikeouts, and 43 walks in 91 innings.<ref name=\"minors\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan hoped to remain in Milwaukee for the 1953 season, because the Braves moved there from Boston. However, he failed to make the team out of spring training this time, and the Braves tried to send him to their new AAA affiliate, the [[Toledo Mud Hens]]. Fearing he would remain in the minor leagues, Donovan requested a trade. “I believed I could win in the major leagues and wanted a chance to prove it,\" he said.<ref name=\"SABR\"/> [[John Quinn (baseball executive)
Jasper, Indiana}}: John Quinn]] denied his request at first, then made him available, but he rejected all deals other teams tried to make for Donovan. Finally, [[Gene Mauch]], Donovan's former roommate and manager of the Braves' [[Class AA (baseball)
column3: Class AA]] affiliate, convinced Donovan to come play for the [[Atlanta Crackers]] of the [[Southern Association]].<ref name=\"SABR\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: \"That was the best thing that ever happened to me,” Donovan said of getting sent to Atlanta. “It brought me under the wing of [[Whitlow Wyatt
Jasper, Indiana}}: [Whitlow] Wyatt]].\"<ref name=\"SABR\"/> A former pitcher for the Dodgers, Wyatt taught Donovan how to throw a [[Slider (baseball)
column4: prospect]] was at Atlanta.<ref name=\"SABR\"/> Donovan appeared in 32 games (19 starts) for Atlanta, posting an 11–8 record, a 3.71 ERA, 132 strikeouts, and 51 walks in 182 innings.<ref name=\"minors\"/> He got his wish after the season, when the Braves sold his contract to the [[Detroit Tigers]].<ref name=\"reference\"/> Donovan made the Tigers out of spring training but only appeared in two games before Detroit returned him to the Braves on May 13.<ref name=\"reference\"/> He was happy to accept another assignment to Atlanta, where Wyatt was now the manager.<ref name=\"SABR\"/> He responded with his best minor league season yet. In 27 games (all starts) for Atlanta, he had an 18–8 record and a 2.69 ERA for the team. Donovan also managed to hit well for the Crackers, slugging 12 [[home run]]s and having 32 [[runs batted in]]. The Crackers won the Southern Association pennant, and Donovan was named their Most Valuable Player.<ref name=\"SABR\"/><ref>{{Cite web
column10: accessdate=March 10, 2020}}</ref> After the minor league season, the [[Chicago White Sox]] purchased his contract from Milwaukee.<ref name=\"reference\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan made the White Sox out of spring training in 1955, as a reliever.<ref name=\"1955 Donovan\">{{cite web
column5: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> However, he was quickly added to the rotation after [[Bob Keegan]], an [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game
column6: All-Star]] who had won 16 games with the White Sox the year before, developed a bone spur on his heel.<ref name=\"slider\">{{cite web
column10: title=No Longer a Team to Be Ignored, the White Sox Loom Large in the American League Race with Speed, Defense and Some Great Pitching
column13: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> He finally got his first career win on April 29, in a four-hit [[Shutout (baseball)
column14: shutout]] of the [[Boston Red Sox]].<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Boston Red Sox at Chicago White Sox Box Score, April 29, 1955
column18: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> At the plate, he hit his first career home run July 3 against [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum
column19: Hall of Famer]] [[Bob Lemon]] in a 14–9 loss to the [[Cleveland Indians]].<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Chicago White Sox at Cleveland Indians Box Score, July 3, 1955
column23: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> With a 10–2 record at the [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game
column24: All-Star break]], Donovan returned to Milwaukee as a member of the [[American League]] (AL) All-Star Team, though he did not pitch in the game.<ref name=\"SABR\"/><ref name=\"1955 Donovan\"/> His record was 13–2 on July 20; Donovan lost his next two starts in July, then suffered appendicitis and missed a month recovering.<ref name=\"1955 Donovan\"/><ref name=\"SABR\"/> He won his first start back on August 21, then went on a five-game losing streak, posting an 8.07 ERA over that span.<ref name=\"1955 Donovan\"/> In his final start of the year, September 24, he threw a five-hit shutout against the [[Kansas City Athletics]].<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=Kansas City Athletics at Chicago White Sox Box Score, September 24, 1955
column28: accessdate=March 26, 2020}}</ref> Donovan finished his first full season in [[Major League Baseball]] (MLB) with a 15–9 record, a 3.32 ERA, five shutouts, 88 strikeouts, and 48 walks in 187 innings.<ref name=\"reference\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In his first start of the 1956 season April 20, Donovan gave up three runs in {{frac
column4: 3}} innings and contributed a two-run home run against [[Lou Kretlow]] of Kansas City; he got a no-decision, but the White Sox won 5–3.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Chicago White Sox at Kansas City Athletics Box Score, April 20, 1956
column8: accessdate=March 27, 2020}}</ref> Wins were few and far between for Donovan, who finished July with a 4–7 record and a 5.02 ERA. A six-game winning streak and a 2.01 ERA in the last two months improved his numbers by season's end.<ref>{{cite web

column14: title=Chicago White Sox at Kansas City Athletics Box Score, August 15, 1956
column16: accessdate=March 27, 2020}}</ref> Against Cleveland on August 31, he matched zeroes on the scoreboard with Hall of Famer [[Early Wynn]] for nine innings, then won the game in the 10th when his RBI [[Single (baseball)
column17: single]] against Wynn gave the White Sox a 1–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Cleveland Indians at Chicago White Sox Box Score, August 31, 1956
column21: accessdate=March 27, 2020}}</ref> In 34 games (31 starts), he had a 12–10 record, a 3.64 ERA, three shutouts, 120 strikeouts, and 59 walks in {{frac
column24: 3}} innings. He led the league with a 1.155 [[walks plus hits per inning pitched]] (WHIP).<ref name=\"reference\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan threw a shutout against Cleveland on May 25, 1957, allowing a second-inning [[Double (baseball)

column9: title=Cleveland Indians at Chicago White Sox Box Score, May 30, 1957
column11: accessdate=March 27, 2020}}</ref> On July 20, Donovan threw another one-hit shutout in a game against the Red Sox, with [[Ted Williams]]'s fourth-inning single being the only hit for Boston.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Boston Red Sox at Chicago White Sox Box Score, July 20, 1957
column15: accessdate=March 19, 2020}}</ref> Possessing an eight and three record on July 3, he won seven games in a row, a streak that did not end until August 29, in an 11-inning, 2–1 loss to the Yankees.<ref>{{cite web
column19: accessdate=March 19, 2020}}</ref> Donovan, as a member of the White Sox, led the {{mlby
column20: 1957}} AL in [[winning percentage]], posting a 16–6 record for a .727 winning percentage. He also led the league with 16 [[complete game]]s and struck out 88 in {{frac
column23: 3}} innings. Donovan finished 13th in AL [[Major League Baseball Most Valuable Player Award
column24: Most Valuable Player (MVP) Award]] voting and came in second to the [[National League]]'s [[Warren Spahn]] in [[Cy Young Award]] voting, in an era where the Cy Young was only presented to one pitcher for both leagues.<ref name=\"reference\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: It looked like Donovan would have the opposite winning percentage in 1958, after he got off to a 3–10 start with an ERA of 4.29.<ref name=\"1958 splits\"/> In the midst of the 3–10 start, on June 15, he shut out the [[Baltimore Orioles]] in the second game of a [[Doubleheader (baseball)

column20: accessdate=March 27, 2020}}</ref> In 34 starts, Donovan had a 15–14 record, a 3.01 ERA, four shutouts, 127 strikeouts, and 58 walks in 248 innings. He had the lowest [[walks per nine innings]] (1.9) of all AL pitchers and finished 25th in MVP voting.<ref name=\"reference\"/>

This was not reflected in his won-loss record, as he finished the season with a 6–1 mark.<ref name=\"reference\"/> Still, the White Sox left him unprotected from the [[1960 Major League Baseball expansion draft

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' did not expect much from Donovan entering the year; their preview of the first-year Senators stated, \"In two seasons, 1957–58, Dick Donovan won 31 games for the White Sox. Perhaps he will remember how he did it.\"<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=March 25, 2020}}</ref> Donovan started the first game in the expansion Senators' history, against his old team, the White Sox. He had a 3–2 lead through the sixth inning, but errors by [[Gene Woodling]] and [[Dale Long]] allowed a couple unearned runs to score, and the Senators lost 4–3. After the game, someone wished Donovan better luck next time; the angry pitcher nearly spit out of rage.<ref>{{cite web
column14: accessdate=March 25, 2020}}</ref> Donovan would often be a tough-luck loser that season, losing his first five decisions of the season by one run, including 1–0 loss to Minnesota on April 23.<ref name=\"Piersall Traded\">{{cite web
column33: accessdate=March 19, 2020}}</ref> He did not win a game until June 2, against Kansas City.<ref name=\"1961 Donovan\"/> For his second victory, Donovan threw a shutout in the first game of a June 9 doubleheader against his old team the White Sox, but it took the Senators 10 innings to get him a run to give him the win.<ref>{{cite web
column35: title=Chicago White Sox at Washington Senators Box Score, June 9, 1961
column37: accessdate=March 19, 2020}}</ref> Through June 30, he was 3–8, but he went 7–2 the rest of the way.<ref name=\"1961 Donovan\"/> Despite his losing record, he was the Senators' lone representative at both of the year's All-Star Games, pitching two scoreless innings in the first one at [[Candlestick Park]]. \"Donovan is a real professional,” Senators' manager [[Mickey Vernon]] said. “He knows how to pitch and gives you an all-out effort. Dick just doesn’t throw the ball -- he has every pitch planned.\"<ref name=\"SABR\"/> His record was just 10–10 at season's end, but his pitching was the best of his career, as his 2.40 ERA (a career-low) led the American League. In {{frac
column40: 3}} innings, he gave up only 138 hits, leading the AL with a 1.026 WHIP. He finished 17th in MVP voting.<ref name=\"reference\"/> Shortly after the season, on October 5, the Senators traded him, [[Gene Green (baseball)
column41: Gene Green]], and [[Jim Mahoney]] to the [[Cleveland Indians]] for [[Jimmy Piersall]].<ref name=\"reference\">{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: With the Indians in 1962, Donovan had better luck.<ref name=\"Bad Luck\"/> Used as the Indians' [[Opening Day]] starter, he shut out the Red Sox on April 10.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Cleveland Indians at Boston Red Sox Box Score, April 10, 1962
column5: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> In fact, he did not allow a run until his third game of the year, starting the season with 19 scoreless innings.<ref name=\"1962 Donovan\">{{cite web
column9: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> He commenced with an 8–0 start, becoming the first pitcher in the major leagues to eight wins on May 24.<ref name=\"Bad Luck\"/> Donovan was selected to the AL All-Star team in both games, allowing a run over two innings in the first one and not pitching in the second one.<ref name=\"SABR\"/> Twice during the year, he hit two home runs in a game—May 18 against Detroit and August 31 against Baltimore; the Indians won both instances.<ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> He limited the Orioles to two hits July 2 in a 2–0 victory.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Baltimore Orioles at Cleveland Indians Box Score, July 2, 1962
column17: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> On August 26, he limited Boston to two hits in a 4–0 victory; the shutout was his third of the year against the Red Sox.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Boston Red Sox at Cleveland Indians Box Score, August 26, 1962
column21: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> During a game on September 4, he limited the White Sox to two runs through 12 innings but took the loss after giving up a run in the 13th.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Cleveland Indians at Chicago White Sox Box Score, September 4, 1962
column25: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> Donovan was rewarded for his performance in 1962, when he won 20 games for the first time in his career. In 34 starts, he had 16 complete games and five shutouts (most in the AL) in 250<small>{{fraction
column27: 3}}</small> innings pitched, all of them new career-highs, for Cleveland. His ERA was 3.59.<ref name=\"reference\"/> After the season, he finished fifth in MVP voting, and the ''[[Sporting News]]'' named him its AL Pitcher of the Year.<ref>{{cite web
column34: page=22}}</ref> The Indians named him their Man of the Year and gave him a $40,000 contract for 1963.<ref name=\"SABR\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Despite his success in 1962, Donovan was the Indians' third starter for 1963, behind [[Mudcat Grant]] and [[Sam McDowell]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> On July 5, he held the Yankees to one run, had two hits, and scored a run in a 4–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=New York Yankees at Cleveland Indians Box Score, July 5, 1963
column9: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> Through August 3, he had a 6–10 record, but he won his next four starts by pitching four complete games in a row, including back-to-back shutouts August 8 and August 14 (when he held the White Sox scoreless for 11 innings in a 1–0 victory).<ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> In 30 starts, he had an 11–13 record, a 4.24 ERA, three shutouts, 84 strikeouts, and 28 walks in 206 innings. For the second year in a row, he led the league in walks per nine innings, with a 1.2 mark.<ref name=\"reference\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan held the [[Los Angeles Angels]] to two runs over eight innings and drove in a couple of his own with a single against [[Ken McBride]] in a 3–2 victory over the Angels on April 23, 1964.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Cleveland Indians at Los Angeles Angels Box Score, April 23, 1964
column5: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> Through August 8, though his record was close to .500 at 6–7, his ERA was 4.72. After that, he was removed from the rotation. Though he made four more starts for the Indians that season, they were all in doubleheaders.<ref>{{cite web
column9: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> Against the White Sox in the second game of a doubleheader during September 6, he relinquished 16 hits but lasted into the 13th inning, when [[Pete Ward]] finally drove in a run to give Chicago a 3–2 victory.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Cleveland Indians at Chicago White Sox Box Score, September 6, 1964
column13: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> In 30 games (just 23 starts), he had a 7–9 record, a 4.55 ERA, no shutouts, 83 strikeouts, and 29 walks in {{frac

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 1965, Donovan was again a starter for the Indians, but only for his first two games, after which he was moved to the bullpen.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=March 29, 2020}}</ref> He had not made it through the sixth inning in either of his starts, and the Indians wanted to give more starts to prospects like [[Sonny Siebert]] and [[Luis Tiant]].<ref name=\"SABR\"/> Used all but once in relief after that, he was released June 15 after posting a 5.96 ERA in 12 games.<ref name=\"reference\"/>  “I figure baseball was good to me,” Donovan said. “I was good to a lot of people in baseball too -- the hitters. It will be nice to take it easy if I don’t go with another club.”<ref name=\"SABR\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: During a 15-year major league career, Donovan compiled 122 wins, 880 strikeouts, and a 3.67 ERA, with 101 complete games, 25 shutouts and five saves. In 2,017<small>{{fraction
column3: 3}}</small> innings pitched, he allowed 1,988 hits and 495 walks.<ref name=\"reference\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Donovan threw three pitches: a [[fastball]], a [[curveball]], and a slider. He learned the slider while pitching for Atlanta, when coach and later manager Whitlow Wyatt helped teach it to him.<ref name=\"SABR\"/> In 1955, when he finally stuck in a major league team's rotation, ''Sports Illustrated'' called it \"one of the most effective pitches in baseball.\"<ref name=\"slider\"/> Among pitchers, Donovan was also an unusually gifted hitter. In 1954, he was the team MVP for Atlanta after hitting 12 home runs and driving in 38 runs in only 27 games.<ref name=\"SABR\"/> With the White Sox, he was frequently used as a pinch-hitter. At the plate in his 15-year major league career, Donovan posted a .163 batting average (113-for-694) with 67 runs, 15 home runs, 64 RBI, and 64 walks.<ref name=\"reference\"/>
On February 7, 1959, Donovan married Patricia Casey, a [[Quincy, Massachusetts
Jasper, Indiana}}: Quincy]], Massachusetts, resident who was a stewardess for [[United Airlines]]. The couple had two children, Peter and Amy. His friend Wyatt gave him the idea to sell insurance, and Donovan had a home business selling insurance during his MLB career. In 1963, he earned his stockbroker's license and joined the Boston-based firm Eastman & Dillon. After his baseball career, he served as the executive vice president for [[Bache & Co.]]. In 1980, he opened a real estate appraisal office in Quincy, which he ran until 1994. Additionally, Donovan served as distributor with Earth Care Products, a Quincy company that makes products out of recycled plastic. He died from cancer on January 6, 1997.<ref name=\"SABR\"/>
