Due to the film's success, a [[sequel]] was written with the script title ''Total Recall 2'', and with Schwarzenegger's character still Douglas Quaid, now working as a reformed law enforcer. The sequel was based on another Philip K. Dick short story, \"[[The Minority Report]]\", which hypothesizes about a future where a crime can be solved before it is committed—in the movie, the [[clairvoyance
Jasper, Indiana}}: clairvoyants]] would be Martian mutants.<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Overview of ''Total Recall'' DVD audio commentary at
column11: df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 1994, producer Mario Kassar spoke with director [[Ronny Yu]] about possibly helming the sequel.<ref>{{cite magazine
column13: title=Yu talks with Kassar about helming \"Total Recall 2\"
column17: accessdate=June 1, 2015 }}</ref> In 1998, actor-director [[Jonathan Frakes]] was also attached to the follow-up.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=The Long, Strange Saga of Total Recall 2
column25: df=mdy-all}}</ref> The sequel ultimately was not filmed, but the script survived and it was changed drastically and contained greater elements from the original short story. The story was eventually adapted into the [[Steven Spielberg]] sci-fi thriller ''[[Minority Report (film)
column26: Minority Report]]'', which opened in 2002 to commercial success.<ref name=\"boxoffice\">{{cite web
column35: title=Home Video (DVD & VHS) Out Sells Feature Films, Video Games and Movies in 2002

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 1997 [[Dimension Films]] acquired sequel, prequel and remake rights to ''Total Recall'' from [[Carolco Pictures]]' bankruptcy auction.<ref>{{cite web

In February 2009, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' stated that [[Neal H. Moritz]] and [[Original Film]] were in negotiations for developing a contemporary version of ''Total Recall'' for Columbia.<ref>{{cite news
column10: df=mdy-all }}</ref> In June 2009, it was announced that [[Columbia Pictures]] had hired [[Kurt Wimmer]] to write the script for the remake. Over a year later, [[Len Wiseman]] was hired to direct.<ref>{{cite magazine
column12: title=Wimmer to write 'Recall' remake—Entertainment News, Film News, Media

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: On January 9, 2011, it was confirmed that [[Colin Farrell]] would be starring in the remake and [[Bryan Cranston]] would play the villain, with production starting in Toronto on May 15. According to Moritz, this version of the film would be closer to Dick's original story. Moritz also stated that the film would not be shot in [[3D film
Jasper, Indiana}}: 3D]], saying \"we decided that it would be too much.\"<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Neal Moritz Interview TOTAL RECALL; Says Colin Farrell Is the Lead, No 3D
column5: website=Collider}}</ref> [[Kate Beckinsale]] was cast in the role of agent Lori,<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Kate Beckinsale has also been set for Total Recall role
column14: df=mdy-all }}</ref> while [[John Cho]] was cast as McClane, the smooth-talking rep for the memory company.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=John Cho signs on for 'Total Recall' -- EXCLUSIVE
column25: df=mdy-all}}</ref> The film was released on August 3, 2012,<ref name=\"Release\">{{cite news
column27: title=Sony Schedules 'Total Recall' For August 2012, Also Dates 'I Hate You, Dad' And Kevin James' MMA Film
column32: accessdate=2012-08-26}}</ref> and received mixed reviews.<ref name=\"RottenTomatoes\">{{cite web

column4: title=Directed by Steven Spielberg: Poetics of the Contemporary Hollywood Blockbuster

tenants = [[Brøndby IF]] (1965–)
Brøndby Atletik (1965–1991)
[[Denmark national football team]] (selected matches)

column4: football]] [[stadium]] in [[Brøndbyvester]], Denmark and the home ground of [[Danish Superliga]] club [[Brøndby IF]]. It is the second largest stadium in [[Denmark]]. Built in 1965 and inaugurated on 31 June 1966 where it had no stands, it saw a major redevelopment in 2000 which increased capacity to 31,500 spectators, of which 19,700 were seated. Continuous adjustments to the spectator facilities have since resulted in the stadium having a total capacity of 28,000 spectators, of which 23,400 are seated. Record attendance dates to 18 June 2003, where a crowd of 31,508 were present in a [[Copenhagen Derby]] against [[F.C. Copenhagen]].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: When hosting the [[UEFA]] competitions [[UEFA Champions League
column3: Europa League]], seats are installed on the South End [[Terrace (stadium)
column5: Sydsiden}}) in accordance with UEFA regulations, which reduces the total capacity to 26,000.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The stadium has also hosted the [[Denmark national football team]] in five matches. Their first game at Brøndby Stadion was a [[exhibition game
column3: Portugal]] on 1 September 2006 which ended in a 4–2 win.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The idea of constructing a centrally located, municipal sports facility was presented by erstwhile mayor [[Jens Christian Jensen (mayor)
Jasper, Indiana}}: Jens Christian Jensen]] in 1945,<ref name=\"Barnak27\">Barnak 2007, p. 27.</ref> but at the time the sports clubs of the municipality could not agree on a common stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak27\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: When a merger of the municipality's three largest sports clubs was considered in the 1950s, much suggests that these plans were fostered on a political as well as executive level.<ref name=\"Barnak27\"/> Having only one club in the municipality would enable a more rational use of a future Brøndby Stadion.<ref name=\"Barnak27\"/> The idea of a merger gained support in [[Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening]], and at the general assembly in 1962 a majority of the board voted their approval of merging [[:da:Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening
column3: Brøndby Strands Idrætsforeninger]].<ref name=\"Barnak28\"/> The latter, however, immediately disapproved of the idea, while a vote in Brøndbyvester ended up with the same result: a 'no' to merging into a municipal superstructure.<ref name=\"Barnak28\">Barnak 2007, p. 28.</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Only a few years would pass before plans of merging Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening and Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening would resurface.<ref name=\"Barnak28\"/> Financial benefit was one of the main arguments for uniting the two clubs in order to play at a future municipal stadium,<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\">{{cite news
column6: date=22 October 2000 }}</ref> and mayor of [[Brøndby Municipality
column7: Brøndby]] in the period 1966–2005, as well as chairman of [[Brøndby IF]] board in 1971–71, [[Kjeld Rasmussen]], has since stated that he and Brøndby's mayor at the time had decided to construct a stadium, provided that the two clubs would merge.<ref name=\"Barnak61\">Barnak 2007, p. 61.</ref> {{quotation
column8: The closer we came to a completion of Brøndby Stadion, the stronger grew the support of forming one big club. Its proponents saw obvious advantages in a merger, which would mean that administrative personnel and athletes would have better physical surroundings to exercise and compete, and finally it would benefit both horisontally and vertically that all energy would become gathered in one club. Eventually, it was suggested that a merger would mean avoiding a reciprocal competitiveness especially in the area of municipal subsidies
column11: Kjeld Rasmussen]], Mayor of Brøndby Municipality, 1966–2005.<ref name=\"Barnak28\"/>}}

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: On 3 December 1964 in Kirkebjerg Salen in [[Brøndbyvester]], the boards of Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening and Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening adopted an agreement to merge into one club: [[Brøndby IF
Jasper, Indiana}}: Brøndbyernes Idrætsforening]] (Brøndby IF).<ref name=\"Rasmussen37\">Rasmussen 2009, pp. 37–38.</ref><ref name=\"64-70\">{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: When the stadium reached its completion in 1965, the ground consisted of nothing more than a grass pitch surrounded by an [[sport of athletics
Jasper, Indiana}}: athletics]] track and a spectator rail circling the field of play, a training complex featuring four grass pitches, and a gravel pitch.<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\"/> Behind one of the goals various athletics facilities were established, as the club shared the stadium with Brøndby Atletik.<ref>{{cite news
column8: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> In addition, a changing room with four separate compartments was constructed, featuring showers and toilet facilities.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/><ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The official inauguration of the pitch was officially planned for late Summer 1965, but issues with making the grass grow postponed the launch to 31 July 1966.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/>

In the following years, the area around Brøndby Stadion continuously developed and expanded; in 1969–70 the municipality constructed additional training pitches South of the ground, close to the [[Danish national road 21
Jasper, Indiana}}: Holbæk Motorway]],<ref name=\"Barnak33\">Barnak 2007, p. 33</ref> and even more training complexes were built South of the motorway in 1972–74.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Conditions around the main playing pitch were also improved; in 1966 two [[turnstile]]s were set up at the stadium entrance,<ref name=\"Barnak33\"/> and in 1969 a clock was added, courtesy of local [[watchmaker]] Bent Henriksen from [[Brøndbyøster Torv]].<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/> In 1973 the municipality allocated [[Danish krone
Jasper, Indiana}}: DKK]] 20,000 to set up a modern loudspeaker system consisting of four ''folded'' [[horn loudspeaker]]s suspended on four-metre steel trusses.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: As [[Brøndby IF]] moved up the ranks, a need arose for a more contemporary stadium. In 1975, the [[Brøndby Municipality
Jasper, Indiana}}: municipality]] allowed the club to improve spectator facilities by installing two-step terraces around the [[running track]].<ref name=\"Barnak72\">Barnak 2007, p. 72</ref> This happened despite the club's wishes to install a covered grandstand.<ref name=\"Barnak72\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Only in 1977, when the club reached promotion to the third highest football league in Denmark, the [[Danish 2nd Division]], did the municipality decide that a covered grandstand should be erected.<ref name=\"Barnak73\"/> The [[Danish krone
Jasper, Indiana}}: DKK]] 4 million project broke ground during the summer of 1978, and in early 1979 the grandstand was ready for use.<ref name=\"Barnak73\">Barnak 2007, p. 73</ref> The stand, which could hold 1,335 seated spectators, and included a [[announcer
column3: speaker]] booth, media facilities and a TV plateau, was placed facing West towards [[Gildhøj (Brøndby Municipality)
column4: Gildhøjskolen]].<ref name=\"Barnak73\"/> Beneath the stand were constructed four dressing rooms, a kiosk, an office, toilet facilities, a storage room as well as the club room of Brøndby Atletik.<ref name=\"Barnak73\"/> In the spring of 1980, the municipality installed the first floodlights with a brightness of 4 x 24 kW.<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\"/> With the new stand, spectator capacity increased to 5,000.<ref name=\"Barnak72\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: As Brøndby IF had reached promotion to the highest football league in Denmark in the fall of 1981, then known as the [[Danish Superliga
Jasper, Indiana}}: 1st Division]], mayor Kjeld Rasmussen proclaimed that a covered stand would be constructed.<ref name=\"Barnak80\">Barnak 2007, p. 80</ref> Prior to the [[1982 Danish 1st Division
column3: 1982 season]] – Brøndby's first on the highest level – concrete [[Terrace (stadium)
column4: terraces]] were installed opposite the existing grandstand, consisting of 13 rows of terraces the length of the pitch in open air.<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg2\">{{cite news
column8: date=22 October 2000 }}</ref> This allowed a crowd of 5,000 additional people,<ref name=\"3. etape\">{{cite news
column15: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> bringing the total capacity to 10,000.

column4: Brøndby Stadion as seen from the South in 2005.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: After the club had established itself in the top of [[Football in Denmark
Jasper, Indiana}}: Danish football]] during the 1980s, Brøndby IF reached a hitherto zenith by reaching the [[1990–91_UEFA_Cup#Quarter-finals
column3: quarter-finals]] of the [[1990–91 UEFA Cup]].<ref name=\"FiB07\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"Rasmussen205207\">Rasmussen 2009, pp. 205–207.</ref> At that time, Brøndby Stadion did not live up to international standards to host matches at that level. However, this was solved by installing temporary end stands of [[scaffolding]], which allowed the club to receive an approval by the [[UEFA]] to organise the home leg against [[FC Torpedo Moscow
column9: Torpedo Moscow]].<ref name=\"FiB07\"/> The changes raised the total capacity to 15,000 spectators, and the club even outdid themselves when they reached the [[1990–91_UEFA_Cup#Semi-finals
column10: semi-finals]] by increasing the capacity to 17,000–18,000.<ref>{{cite news
column17: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> In the same period Brøndby IF submitted a bid to host the [[Denmark national football team]] at a new national stadium; a \"''Stadion Danmark''\", which would seat 60,000 spectators and border the [[Danish national road 21
column18: Holbæk Motorway]].<ref name=\"FiB07\" /> These plans, however, never came to fruition as [[Parken Stadium]] won the bid and eventually became the national stadium.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: As Brøndby IF gained domestic and European success, spectator interest had grown to such a degree, that it became necessary to move the biggest matches to [[Københavns Idrætspark]].<ref name=\"4. etape\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=10 April 2020 }}</ref> This solution was not deemed satisfactory for neither club, fans nor sponsors, who wanted to remain rooted in the local community.<ref name=\"4. etape\"/><ref name=\"FiB07\"/> Therefore, the board under leadership of [[Per Bjerregaard]], decided to plan an expansion of Brøndby Stadion.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\">Barnak 2007, pp. 139-140</ref> The first step was taken in 1990, when the stand opposite the grandstand was covered and expanded with eight rows, holding 3,500 seated spectators, as well as terracing holding 10,500 standing spectators in total.<ref name=\"BT 1991-03-12\">{{cite news
column13: page=2 }}</ref> In the same year the grandstand was expanded with a lounge for sponsors in which a panoramic window allowed for a view of the entire pitch.<ref name=\"FiB07\"/> While Brøndby Municipality had financed the new covered stand, Brøndby IF funded the construction of the sponsors lounge.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Despite improved spectator facilities, the stadium did still not live up to UEFA requirements,<ref name=\"6. etape\">{{cite web
column5: accessdate=8 December 2014}}</ref> and the club wished to erect permanent terracing behind both goals.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> As this would mean that the running track around the pitch had to be demolished, and that Brøndby Atletik would have to be compensated with a new running track elsewhere,<ref name=\"BT-1991-06-12\">{{cite news
column12: page=34 }}</ref> the municipality chose to turn down Brøndby IF's application to further expand the stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\">Barnak 2007, pp. 139-140</ref> This made the club consider moving to another city where it would be able to host international games,<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> prompting the municipality to offer Brøndby IF to acquire the stadium and thus raise money to construct an athletics stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> The club board, spearheaded by Bjerregaard, was, however, only interested in purchasing the area behind the two goals.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> Brøndby IF had meanwhile offered to pay for construction costs of the end stands themselves, but in order to do so the pitch had to be expanded both in width and length.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 1991, the municipal council decided that Brøndby IF should have the sole right to use the stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak140141\">Barnak 2007, pp. 140-141</ref> Thus, a green light was finally given to turn Brøndby Stadion into a [[Soccer-specific stadium
Jasper, Indiana}}: football-specific stadium]]. In December 1991, the contractor began removing the running track,<ref name=\"Barnak140141\"/> and in the spring of 1992, the expanded Brøndby Stadion has reached completion: four covered stands with a total capacity of almost 21,000 spectators.<ref name=\"BT 1991-02-13\">{{cite news
column16: page=28 }}</ref> This included the infamous terraced \"South Side\"-end ({{lang-da
column18: Faxe]] Tribunen'' for sponsorship reasons – which was inaugurated on 29 March 1992.<ref name=\"6. etape\"/> With the 1,335 seats on the main grandstand and another 3,000 new seats on the lower side of the opposite stand, the stadium could hold more than 6,000 seated spectators.<ref name=\"Barnak141\">Barnak 2007, p. 141</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Despite several expansions and improvements over the years, Brøndby Stadion could still not achieve acceptable capacity for international matches, and the club was therefore forced to rent [[Parken Stadium]] in [[Indre Østerbro]] – home of the [[Denmark national football team
Jasper, Indiana}}: national team]] as well as archrivals [[F.C. Copenhagen
column3: FC Copenhagen]] – for major matches under [[UEFA]].<ref name=\"6. etape\"/> This resulted in losses; both on a financial level, but also in terms of prestige, and because of this the board continued to work on plans of further expanding the stadium.<ref name=\"6. etape\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The first step was commencing negotiations with [[Brøndby Municipality]] in order to secure the total acquisition of the stadium, and as a result of the proceedings, [[Brøndby IF]] [[Aktieselskab
Jasper, Indiana}}: A/S]] purchased Brøndby Stadion for [[Danish krone
column3: DKK]] 23.5 million in May 1998.<ref name=\"Reuters 1998-05-14\">{{cite news
column4: title=Brøndby køber eget stadion for 23,5 mio - BIF
column11: date=14 May 1998}}</ref> From this, DKK 16 million was to be deducted for the two end stands and the sponsors lounge,<ref name=\"Reuters 1998-05-14\"/> which the club itself had financed, resulting in a final amount of DKK 7.3 million.<ref name=\"Barnak180\">Barnak 2007, p. 180</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The acquisition officially took place on 1 January 1999,<ref name=\"Barnak180\"/> after which the largest expansion of Brøndby Stadion could commence;<ref name=\"Reuters 1998-11-02\">{{cite news
column4: date=2 November 1998 }}</ref> a connected upper stand supported by a total of 32 concrete [[Staircase tower
column5: staircase towers]],<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> and a new roof carried by a total of 32 m tall iron structures, each 25 m apart.<ref name=\"Barnak180\"/> These would – together with the existing lower stands – ensure that the stadium could bring the total spectator capacity to more than 30,000 for [[UEFA
column8: title=Nyt stadion øger Brøndby-res 15-20 mio - prospekt
column10: date=19 October 1998 }}</ref> The total costs for the expansion were DKK 270 million,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\">{{cite web
column15: accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> 40 million more than original estimates due to costs spiralling.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2001\">{{cite web
column19: page=9 }}</ref> In addition to the new upper stand section, the main grandstand was expanded with a superstructure.<ref>{{cite news
column22: title=Ny tribune står klar til næste år
column24: publisher=Politiken, section 1 page 19}}</ref> Not least, the sponsor and lounge areas were expanded considerably,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> and a new three-storey annex providing administrative offices, press facilities, commercial kitchen and lounge areas able to host more than 3,000 was erected facing the parking lot.<ref name=\"Barnak181\">Barnak 2007, p. 181</ref> On the ground floor were constructed additional facilies, including a lobby, a gym for the players and a fanshop.<ref name=\"Barnak181\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The connected upper stands meant that the corners of the stadium became partly enclosed, and toilet stalls as well as food and drink outlets were placed in the spaces between the lower and upper stands.<ref name=\"Barnak181\"/> The new upper stands included 13,600 new seats, increasing the total capacity to 31,500 spectators.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> For international matches, capacity was limited to 26,500 spectators as they demand [[all-seater
Jasper, Indiana}}: all-seated]] crowds.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> The entire redevelopment was carried out while the club still played its home games at the stadium, and the original changing rooms under the main grandstand, originating from 1978, were retained.<ref name=\"Barnak181\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The stadium officially reopened with a ceremony on 22 October 2000,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> followed by an [[exhibition game]] between the [[Brøndby IF]] team from 1989 and [[:da:Skagen Idræts Klub
Jasper, Indiana}}: Skagen IK]]; a rematch mirroring a [[1986–87 Danish Cup]] game, where Skagen from the Danish fifth tier knocked out Brøndby after a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)
column3: penalty-shootout]], in what has been described as \"the biggest sensation in Danish Cup history\".<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/><ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Da Skagen IK slog Brøndby: 'Det største jeg har oplevet i mit sportsliv'
column11: date=27 April 2017}}</ref> The first competitive game after the rebuild occurred on 22 October 2000 with a 4–2 league win over [[Akademisk Boldklub]] in front of 28,416 spectators.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The stadium reached total completion in 2001.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> The redevelopment also made Brøndby Stadion a part of the Nordic countries' [[UEFA Euro 2008 bids
Jasper, Indiana}}: bid]] for hosting the [[UEFA Euro 2008]], which was eventually awarded to [[Austria]]–[[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Because the total costs of the 1999–2000 expansion exceeded the originally planned budget by [[Danish krone
Jasper, Indiana}}: DKK]] 30–40 million, some major and minor additions and improvements to audience facilities were postponed and subsequently carried out over time.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2001\"/><ref name=\"Barnak181\"/> First of foremost, the club could not afford new turnstiles, and a planned, highly modern entrance system was only installed in 2003, just as the scoreboards initally did not meet the requirements of the [[Danish Football Union]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=4 March 2017}}</ref> The original substitutes' benches in the [[technical area]] likewise had to be utilised for some years before being permanently replaced by benches below pitch-level in 2005.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2005\">{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The new blue seats planned for the lower stands would initially have to wait; firstly, the old, worn-out seats were retained on the two original longside stands, which in the first years following the rebuild appeared as gray, red, yellow and light blue seats. Secondly, seats were expected to be fitted to the extended section of the old grandstand and the lower section of the northern end stand. However, an extra \"row 34\" was added relatively quickly all the way around the top of the stands, in front of the glass partitions.

As new dark blue seats were installed on the aforementioned areas in 2003, a total seating capacity reached 23,400. This increased total stadium capacity to 29,000,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2003\">{{cite web
column6: page=11}}</ref> while the stadium could hold crowds of 26,144 for international matches.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2003\"/> This was due to the fact that for international fixtures, the South Side-end [[Terrace (stadium)
column7: terracing]] could be converted into approximately 2,600 seats.<ref>{{cite web
column15: date=13 March 2004}}</ref> Despite many delayed improvements to the stadium, the redevelopment in 2000 already had already secured improved facilities for wheelchair users, as a wheelchair lift had been installed at the southern end of the East Stand.<ref name=\"stadionoverblik\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 2006–2007, the East Stand (today known as ''GSV Stand'' ({{lang-da
Jasper, Indiana}}: GSV-tribunen}}) for sponsorship reasons) was further expanded at the back with a lounge for sponsors, classrooms for [[:da:Brøndby Gymnasium
column4: general upper secondary education]]), a public gym, a production kitchen and the sports bar \"''1964''\".<ref name=\"RB Børsen 2006-03-07\">{{cite news
column5: title=Brøndby opfører ny bygning på Brøndby Stadion for 90 mio (Opd)
column11: accessdate=11 April 2020 }}</ref> In addition, spectator conditions were improved upon with six new multi-stalls and three new staircases beneath the East Stand.<ref name=\"9. etape\"/> Two large [[Light-emitting diodes
column12: LED]] screens were also installed during this period.<ref name=\"9. etape\"/> The total cost of the project ran up to DKK 90 million.<ref name=\"RB Børsen 2006-03-07\"/>

column3: KasiGroup]] financed a decoration of the Brøndby Stadion facade;<ref name=\"BT 2014-12-03\">{{cite news
column6: title=Gaver til fødselaren: Det har Brøndby modtaget gennem tiden
column9: date=3 December 2014 }}</ref> yellow, illuminated letters with the stadium name affixed between the roof and the top row of seating at three of the stands.<ref name=\"10. etape\">{{cite web
column13: accessdate=8 December 2012 }}</ref> In addition, each [[gable]] was adorned with four large images that showed [[Brøndby IF]] players and fans in different situations.<ref name=\"10. etape\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: During the winter break in of the [[2017–18 Brøndby IF season
Jasper, Indiana}}: 2017–18 season]], the hole on the South Side-end was closed which meant that an additional 75 seats and extra capacity for 150 standing spectators on terracing were added to the stadium.<ref name=\"TipsSyd\">{{cite web
column4: title=Brøndby-fans betaler selv ombygningen af Sydsiden
column8: author=Lasse Sylvest Mikkelsen}}</ref> The rebuild was financed by the club's fans, through the official fanclub ''[[Brøndby_IF#Support
column9: Brøndby Support]]'' and various unofficial fan groups,<ref name=\"TipsSyd\"/> and through a so-called \"fan fund\" which arose as a result of season tickets and merchandise sales, among other things.<ref name=\"VaerMed\">{{cite web
column11: title=Vær med til at forbedre Sydsiden
column14: work=[[Brøndby IF]]}}</ref> In total, the renovation costs amounted to DKK 450,000, of which the fan fund accounted for DKK 270,000.<ref name=\"TipsSyd\"/><ref name=\"VaerMed\"/> In the summer of 2018, new 256 LED floodlights were installed, produced in China.<ref name=\"Lys2018\">{{cite web
column16: title=Nyt lys skal langtidssikre Brøndby Stadion

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The Brøndby Stadion pitch is surrounded by four covered stands, officially known as Sydsiden (South), GSV-tribunen (East), J. Jensen-tribunen (North) and Carlsberg-tribunen (West). Three stands are all-seaters (except the away section on the North End) while the South End is terracing. Each stand has two tiers.

Sydsiden, literally \"South Side\" in English, was inaugurated as the new South Stand on 29 March 1992 in a match against [[Lyngby Boldklub]], due to a rise in interest for Brøndby IF.<ref name=\"FiB07\"/><ref name=Sydsiden2>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=15 March}}</ref> The lower part of the stand has a standing capacity of 5,600 spectators. Initially, spectators would sit on the terraces,<ref name=Sydsiden>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref> but younger fans would begin encouraging all fans on Sydsiden to stand up, because they thought that it was easier to sing while standing, which would evolve into the mantra \"sing or piss off\" ({{lang-da
column12: syng eller skrid}}).<ref name=Sydsiden/> This would mark the beginning of a hard-core fan-culture formation on Sydsiden, which has remained ever since, and it is known as the stand in Denmark with the most dedicated and loudest fans when Brøndby plays its home games.<ref name=\"6. etape\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Until 6 March 2011, Sydsiden was known by its sponsor name, \"Faxe Tribunen\", a subsidiary of [[Royal Unibrew]]. This had to change as there was a conflict of interest as [[Carlsberg Group
Jasper, Indiana}}: Carlsberg]] moved in as new sponsors. Sydsiden was chosen by a panel representing a broad section of the active fan base at Brøndby Stadion, as fans had called the stand this before.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=4 March 2017}}</ref> Halfway through the 2017–18 season, the hole in the middle of the stand was partly closed, after continuous requests by fans.<ref name=\"VaerMed\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: A permanent fanzone was inaugurated outside Sydsiden in 2018 for spectators and fans before, during and after the games. The fanzone is the first of its kind in Scandinavia, and consists of stands for live concerts, bars, foodstands and toilet facilities.

Sydsiden popularised the \"Fenerbahçe greeting\" in Denmark, imported through the transfer of [[Brian Steen Nielsen]] to the Turkish club. A cooperation between goalkeeper [[Mogens Krogh]] and [[Brøndby IF#Support
Jasper, Indiana}}: Brøndby Support]] effectually made the greeting get foothold in Denmark.<ref name=Sydsiden/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The North Stand, now known as \"J. Jensen-tribunen\" for sponsorship reasons, was originally known as \"da:OBS!-tribunen\". The lower section of the stand was constructed in 1992 as terracing, and has among fans been known as \"Pølseenden\" ({{lang-da
column3: the sausage end]]}}) due to its former major sponsor, sausage producer Steff-Houlberg. Fans from the away team are assigned a section on this stand, usually in the eastern part of the North Stand, separated from Brøndby's home fans.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The West Stand, known as \"[[Carlsberg Group
Jasper, Indiana}}: Carlsberg]]-tribunen\", was originally named \"Frisko-tribunen and later also \"SAS-tribunen\" and \"Apollo-tribunen\". The original part of the stand was completed in 1979 as the first stand of the stadium, and it has been preserved through the large expansion in 1999–2000. It can also accommodate a few fans in executive boxes and hospitality suites, and is the ground's main grandstand.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The East Stand, now known as \"GSV-tribunen\" for sponsorship reasons, was formerly called \"LOXAM-tribunen\", \"[[Codan]]-tribunen and \"DNE-tribunen\". The lower section of the stand was constructed in 1982 and 1990. The East Stand was originally without a roof, and consisted of terraces. Today, it is the largest stand of Brøndby Stadion with a total of 34 rows of seats. In 2006, a larger extension was established behind the stand from the facade, consisting of sponsor facilities, a sports bar and classrooms for Brøndby Gymnasium. The classrooms were inaugurated on 8 January 2007. In April 2018, a new family lounge was opened behind the East Stand with both physical and Esports facilities.

The easiest way of getting to the stadium with public transport is with the [[S-tog]] or S-train. Line B (green) will stop at both Brøndbyøster and Glostrup stations, where there are shuttle buses on match days. One can also walk from the stations, with the walk taking 15 minutes from Glostrup, and slightly longer from Brøndbyøster.
Brøndby Stadion has been used five times as home ground for the [[Denmark national football team
Jasper, Indiana}}: Danish national team]]. Further it has been the venue of four youth national matches and a league national match:<ref>{{cite web

column13: [[1987 UEFA European Under-16 Football Championship]] qualifying

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: [[Category:Buildings and structures in Brøndby Municipality]]","{{Expand Danish

Jasper, Indiana}}: location          = [[List of postal codes in Denmark#Zealand (1000-3699 and 4000-4999)

[[Denmark national football team]] (selected matches)

column4: football]] [[stadium]] in [[Brøndbyvester]], Denmark and the home ground of [[Danish Superliga]] club [[Brøndby IF]]. It is the second largest stadium in [[Denmark]]. Built in 1965 and inaugurated on 31 June 1966 where it had no stands, it saw a major redevelopment in 2000 which increased capacity to 31,500 spectators, of which 19,700 were seated. Continuous adjustments to the spectator facilities have since resulted in the stadium having a total capacity of 28,000 spectators, of which 23,400 are seated. Record attendance dates to 18 June 2003, where a crowd of 31,508 were present in a [[Copenhagen Derby]] against [[F.C. Copenhagen]].

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: When hosting the [[UEFA]] competitions [[UEFA Champions League
column3: Europa League]], seats are installed on the South End [[Terrace (stadium)
column5: Sydsiden}}) in accordance with UEFA regulations, which reduces the total capacity to 26,000.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The stadium has also hosted the [[Denmark national football team]] in five matches. Their first game at Brøndby Stadion was a [[exhibition game
column3: Portugal]] on 1 September 2006 which ended in a 4–2 win.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The idea of constructing a centrally located, municipal sports facility was presented by erstwhile mayor [[Jens Christian Jensen (mayor)
Jasper, Indiana}}: Jens Christian Jensen]] in 1945,<ref name=\"Barnak27\">Barnak 2007, p. 27.</ref> but at the time the sports clubs of the municipality could not agree on a common stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak27\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: When a merger of the municipality's three largest sports clubs was considered in the 1950s, much suggests that these plans were fostered on a political as well as executive level.<ref name=\"Barnak27\"/> Having only one club in the municipality would enable a more rational use of a future Brøndby Stadion.<ref name=\"Barnak27\"/> The idea of a merger gained support in [[Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening]], and at the general assembly in 1962 a majority of the board voted their approval of merging [[:da:Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening
column3: Brøndby Strands Idrætsforeninger]].<ref name=\"Barnak28\"/> The latter, however, immediately disapproved of the idea, while a vote in Brøndbyvester ended up with the same result: a 'no' to merging into a municipal superstructure.<ref name=\"Barnak28\">Barnak 2007, p. 28.</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Only a few years would pass before plans of merging Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening and Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening would resurface.<ref name=\"Barnak28\"/> Financial benefit was one of the main arguments for uniting the two clubs in order to play at a future municipal stadium,<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\">{{cite news
column6: date=22 October 2000 }}</ref> and mayor of [[Brøndby Municipality
column7: Brøndby]] in the period 1966–2005, as well as chairman of [[Brøndby IF]] board in 1971–71, [[Kjeld Rasmussen]], has since stated that he and Brøndby's mayor at the time had decided to construct a stadium, provided that the two clubs would merge.<ref name=\"Barnak61\">Barnak 2007, p. 61.</ref> {{quotation
column8: The closer we came to a completion of Brøndby Stadion, the stronger grew the support of forming one big club. Its proponents saw obvious advantages in a merger, which would mean that administrative personnel and athletes would have better physical surroundings to exercise and compete, and finally it would benefit both horisontally and vertically that all energy would become gathered in one club. Eventually, it was suggested that a merger would mean avoiding a reciprocal competitiveness especially in the area of municipal subsidies
column11: Kjeld Rasmussen]], Mayor of Brøndby Municipality, 1966–2005.<ref name=\"Barnak28\"/>}}

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: On 3 December 1964 in Kirkebjerg Salen in [[Brøndbyvester]], the boards of Brøndbyvester Idrætsforening and Brøndbyøster Idrætsforening adopted an agreement to merge into one club: [[Brøndby IF
Jasper, Indiana}}: Brøndbyernes Idrætsforening]] (Brøndby IF).<ref name=\"Rasmussen37\">Rasmussen 2009, pp. 37–38.</ref><ref name=\"64-70\">{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: When the stadium reached its completion in 1965, the ground consisted of nothing more than a grass pitch surrounded by an [[sport of athletics
Jasper, Indiana}}: athletics]] track and a spectator rail circling the field of play, a training complex featuring four grass pitches, and a gravel pitch.<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\"/> Behind one of the goals various athletics facilities were established, as the club shared the stadium with Brøndby Atletik.<ref>{{cite news
column8: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> In addition, a changing room with four separate compartments was constructed, featuring showers and toilet facilities.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/><ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The official inauguration of the pitch was officially planned for late Summer 1965, but issues with making the grass grow postponed the launch to 31 July 1966.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/>

In the following years, the area around Brøndby Stadion continuously developed and expanded; in 1969–70 the municipality constructed additional training pitches South of the ground, close to the [[Danish national road 21
Jasper, Indiana}}: Holbæk Motorway]],<ref name=\"Barnak33\">Barnak 2007, p. 33</ref> and even more training complexes were built South of the motorway in 1972–74.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Conditions around the main playing pitch were also improved; in 1966 two [[turnstile]]s were set up at the stadium entrance,<ref name=\"Barnak33\"/> and in 1969 a clock was added, courtesy of local [[watchmaker]] Bent Henriksen from [[Brøndbyøster Torv]].<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/> In 1973 the municipality allocated [[Danish krone
Jasper, Indiana}}: DKK]] 20,000 to set up a modern loudspeaker system consisting of four ''folded'' [[horn loudspeaker]]s suspended on four-metre steel trusses.<ref name=\"Barnak3233\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: As [[Brøndby IF]] moved up the ranks, a need arose for a more contemporary stadium. In 1975, the [[Brøndby Municipality
Jasper, Indiana}}: municipality]] allowed the club to improve spectator facilities by installing two-step terraces around the [[running track]].<ref name=\"Barnak72\">Barnak 2007, p. 72</ref> This happened despite the club's wishes to install a covered grandstand.<ref name=\"Barnak72\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Only in 1977, when the club reached promotion to the third highest football league in Denmark, the [[Danish 2nd Division]], did the municipality decide that a covered grandstand should be erected.<ref name=\"Barnak73\"/> The [[Danish krone
Jasper, Indiana}}: DKK]] 4 million project broke ground during the summer of 1978, and in early 1979 the grandstand was ready for use.<ref name=\"Barnak73\">Barnak 2007, p. 73</ref> The stand, which could hold 1,335 seated spectators, and included a [[announcer
column3: speaker]] booth, media facilities and a TV plateau, was placed facing West towards [[Gildhøj (Brøndby Municipality)
column4: Gildhøjskolen]].<ref name=\"Barnak73\"/> Beneath the stand were constructed four dressing rooms, a kiosk, an office, toilet facilities, a storage room as well as the club room of Brøndby Atletik.<ref name=\"Barnak73\"/> In the spring of 1980, the municipality installed the first floodlights with a brightness of 4 x 24 kW.<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg\"/> With the new stand, spectator capacity increased to 5,000.<ref name=\"Barnak72\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: As Brøndby IF had reached promotion to the highest football league in Denmark in the fall of 1981, then known as the [[Danish Superliga
Jasper, Indiana}}: 1st Division]], mayor Kjeld Rasmussen proclaimed that a covered stand would be constructed.<ref name=\"Barnak80\">Barnak 2007, p. 80</ref> Prior to the [[1982 Danish 1st Division
column3: 1982 season]] – Brøndby's first on the highest level – concrete [[Terrace (stadium)
column4: terraces]] were installed opposite the existing grandstand, consisting of 13 rows of terraces the length of the pitch in open air.<ref name=\"Stadion tillaeg2\">{{cite news
column8: date=22 October 2000 }}</ref> This allowed a crowd of 5,000 additional people,<ref name=\"3. etape\">{{cite news
column15: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> bringing the total capacity to 10,000.

column4: Brøndby Stadion as seen from the South in 2005.]]

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: After the club had established itself in the top of [[Football in Denmark
Jasper, Indiana}}: Danish football]] during the 1980s, Brøndby IF reached a hitherto zenith by reaching the [[1990–91_UEFA_Cup#Quarter-finals
column3: quarter-finals]] of the [[1990–91 UEFA Cup]].<ref name=\"FiB07\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref><ref name=\"Rasmussen205207\">Rasmussen 2009, pp. 205–207.</ref> At that time, Brøndby Stadion did not live up to international standards to host matches at that level. However, this was solved by installing temporary end stands of [[scaffolding]], which allowed the club to receive an approval by the [[UEFA]] to organise the home leg against [[FC Torpedo Moscow
column9: Torpedo Moscow]].<ref name=\"FiB07\"/> The changes raised the total capacity to 15,000 spectators, and the club even outdid themselves when they reached the [[1990–91_UEFA_Cup#Semi-finals
column10: semi-finals]] by increasing the capacity to 17,000–18,000.<ref>{{cite news
column17: accessdate=9 April 2020}}</ref> In the same period Brøndby IF submitted a bid to host the [[Denmark national football team]] at a new national stadium; a \"''Stadion Danmark''\", which would seat 60,000 spectators and border the [[Danish national road 21
column18: Holbæk Motorway]].<ref name=\"FiB07\" /> These plans, however, never came to fruition as [[Parken Stadium]] won the bid and eventually became the national stadium.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: As Brøndby IF gained domestic and European success, spectator interest had grown to such a degree, that it became necessary to move the biggest matches to [[Københavns Idrætspark]].<ref name=\"4. etape\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=10 April 2020 }}</ref> This solution was not deemed satisfactory for neither club, fans nor sponsors, who wanted to remain rooted in the local community.<ref name=\"4. etape\"/><ref name=\"FiB07\"/> Therefore, the board under leadership of [[Per Bjerregaard]], decided to plan an expansion of Brøndby Stadion.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\">Barnak 2007, pp. 139-140</ref> The first step was taken in 1990, when the stand opposite the grandstand was covered and expanded with eight rows, holding 3,500 seated spectators, as well as terracing holding 10,500 standing spectators in total.<ref name=\"BT 1991-03-12\">{{cite news
column13: page=2 }}</ref> In the same year the grandstand was expanded with a lounge for sponsors in which a panoramic window allowed for a view of the entire pitch.<ref name=\"FiB07\"/> While Brøndby Municipality had financed the new covered stand, Brøndby IF funded the construction of the sponsors lounge.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Despite improved spectator facilities, the stadium did still not live up to UEFA requirements,<ref name=\"6. etape\">{{cite web
column5: accessdate=8 December 2014}}</ref> and the club wished to erect permanent terracing behind both goals.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> As this would mean that the running track around the pitch had to be demolished, and that Brøndby Atletik would have to be compensated with a new running track elsewhere,<ref name=\"BT-1991-06-12\">{{cite news
column12: page=34 }}</ref> the municipality chose to turn down Brøndby IF's application to further expand the stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\">Barnak 2007, pp. 139-140</ref> This made the club consider moving to another city where it would be able to host international games,<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> prompting the municipality to offer Brøndby IF to acquire the stadium and thus raise money to construct an athletics stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> The club board, spearheaded by Bjerregaard, was, however, only interested in purchasing the area behind the two goals.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/> Brøndby IF had meanwhile offered to pay for construction costs of the end stands themselves, but in order to do so the pitch had to be expanded both in width and length.<ref name=\"Barnak139140\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 1991, the municipal council decided that Brøndby IF should have the sole right to use the stadium.<ref name=\"Barnak140141\">Barnak 2007, pp. 140-141</ref> Thus, a green light was finally given to turn Brøndby Stadion into a [[Soccer-specific stadium
Jasper, Indiana}}: football-specific stadium]]. In December 1991, the contractor began removing the running track,<ref name=\"Barnak140141\"/> and in the spring of 1992, the expanded Brøndby Stadion has reached completion: four covered stands with a total capacity of almost 21,000 spectators.<ref name=\"BT 1991-02-13\">{{cite news
column16: page=28 }}</ref> This included the infamous terraced \"South Side\"-end ({{lang-da
column18: Faxe]] Tribunen'' for sponsorship reasons – which was inaugurated on 29 March 1992.<ref name=\"6. etape\"/> With the 1,335 seats on the main grandstand and another 3,000 new seats on the lower side of the opposite stand, the stadium could hold more than 6,000 seated spectators.<ref name=\"Barnak141\">Barnak 2007, p. 141</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Despite several expansions and improvements over the years, Brøndby Stadion could still not achieve acceptable capacity for international matches, and the club was therefore forced to rent [[Parken Stadium]] in [[Indre Østerbro]] – home of the [[Denmark national football team
Jasper, Indiana}}: national team]] as well as archrivals [[F.C. Copenhagen
column3: FC Copenhagen]] – for major matches under [[UEFA]].<ref name=\"6. etape\"/> This resulted in losses; both on a financial level, but also in terms of prestige, and because of this the board continued to work on plans of further expanding the stadium.<ref name=\"6. etape\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The first step was commencing negotiations with [[Brøndby Municipality]] in order to secure the total acquisition of the stadium, and as a result of the proceedings, [[Brøndby IF]] [[Aktieselskab
Jasper, Indiana}}: A/S]] purchased Brøndby Stadion for [[Danish krone
column3: DKK]] 23.5 million in May 1998.<ref name=\"Reuters 1998-05-14\">{{cite news
column4: title=Brøndby køber eget stadion for 23,5 mio - BIF
column11: date=14 May 1998}}</ref> From this, DKK 16 million was to be deducted for the two end stands and the sponsors lounge,<ref name=\"Reuters 1998-05-14\"/> which the club itself had financed, resulting in a final amount of DKK 7.3 million.<ref name=\"Barnak180\">Barnak 2007, p. 180</ref>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The acquisition officially took place on 1 January 1999,<ref name=\"Barnak180\"/> after which the largest expansion of Brøndby Stadion could commence;<ref name=\"Reuters 1998-11-02\">{{cite news
column4: date=2 November 1998 }}</ref> a connected upper stand supported by a total of 32 concrete [[Staircase tower
column5: staircase towers]],<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> and a new roof carried by a total of 32 m tall iron structures, each 25 m apart.<ref name=\"Barnak180\"/> These would – together with the existing lower stands – ensure that the stadium could bring the total spectator capacity to more than 30,000 for [[UEFA
column8: title=Nyt stadion øger Brøndby-res 15-20 mio - prospekt
column10: date=19 October 1998 }}</ref> The total costs for the expansion were DKK 270 million,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\">{{cite web
column15: accessdate=17 January 2015}}</ref> 40 million more than original estimates due to costs spiralling.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2001\">{{cite web
column19: page=9 }}</ref> In addition to the new upper stand section, the main grandstand was expanded with a superstructure.<ref>{{cite news
column22: title=Ny tribune står klar til næste år
column24: publisher=Politiken, section 1 page 19}}</ref> Not least, the sponsor and lounge areas were expanded considerably,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> and a new three-storey annex providing administrative offices, press facilities, commercial kitchen and lounge areas able to host more than 3,000 was erected facing the parking lot.<ref name=\"Barnak181\">Barnak 2007, p. 181</ref> On the ground floor were constructed additional facilies, including a lobby, a gym for the players and a fanshop.<ref name=\"Barnak181\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The connected upper stands meant that the corners of the stadium became partly enclosed, and toilet stalls as well as food and drink outlets were placed in the spaces between the lower and upper stands.<ref name=\"Barnak181\"/> The new upper stands included 13,600 new seats, increasing the total capacity to 31,500 spectators.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> For international matches, capacity was limited to 26,500 spectators as they demand [[all-seater
Jasper, Indiana}}: all-seated]] crowds.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> The entire redevelopment was carried out while the club still played its home games at the stadium, and the original changing rooms under the main grandstand, originating from 1978, were retained.<ref name=\"Barnak181\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The stadium officially reopened with a ceremony on 22 October 2000,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> followed by an [[exhibition game]] between the [[Brøndby IF]] team from 1989 and [[:da:Skagen Idræts Klub
Jasper, Indiana}}: Skagen IK]]; a rematch mirroring a [[1986–87 Danish Cup]] game, where Skagen from the Danish fifth tier knocked out Brøndby after a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)
column3: penalty-shootout]], in what has been described as \"the biggest sensation in Danish Cup history\".<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/><ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Da Skagen IK slog Brøndby: 'Det største jeg har oplevet i mit sportsliv'
column11: date=27 April 2017}}</ref> The first competitive game after the rebuild occurred on 22 October 2000 with a 4–2 league win over [[Akademisk Boldklub]] in front of 28,416 spectators.<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The stadium reached total completion in 2001.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2000\"/> The redevelopment also made Brøndby Stadion a part of the Nordic countries' [[UEFA Euro 2008 bids
Jasper, Indiana}}: bid]] for hosting the [[UEFA Euro 2008]], which was eventually awarded to [[Austria]]–[[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Because the total costs of the 1999–2000 expansion exceeded the originally planned budget by [[Danish krone
Jasper, Indiana}}: DKK]] 30–40 million, some major and minor additions and improvements to audience facilities were postponed and subsequently carried out over time.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2001\"/><ref name=\"Barnak181\"/> First of foremost, the club could not afford new turnstiles, and a planned, highly modern entrance system was only installed in 2003, just as the scoreboards initally did not meet the requirements of the [[Danish Football Union]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=4 March 2017}}</ref> The original substitutes' benches in the [[technical area]] likewise had to be utilised for some years before being permanently replaced by benches below pitch-level in 2005.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2005\">{{cite web

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The new blue seats planned for the lower stands would initially have to wait; firstly, the old, worn-out seats were retained on the two original longside stands, which in the first years following the rebuild appeared as gray, red, yellow and light blue seats. Secondly, seats were expected to be fitted to the extended section of the old grandstand and the lower section of the northern end stand. However, an extra \"row 34\" was added relatively quickly all the way around the top of the stands, in front of the glass partitions.

As new dark blue seats were installed on the aforementioned areas in 2003, a total seating capacity reached 23,400. This increased total stadium capacity to 29,000,<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2003\">{{cite web
column6: page=11}}</ref> while the stadium could hold crowds of 26,144 for international matches.<ref name=\"Årsrapport 2003\"/> This was due to the fact that for international fixtures, the South Side-end [[Terrace (stadium)
column7: terracing]] could be converted into approximately 2,600 seats.<ref>{{cite web
column15: date=13 March 2004}}</ref> Despite many delayed improvements to the stadium, the redevelopment in 2000 already had already secured improved facilities for wheelchair users, as a wheelchair lift had been installed at the southern end of the East Stand.<ref name=\"stadionoverblik\" />

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: In 2006–2007, the East Stand (today known as ''GSV Stand'' ({{lang-da
Jasper, Indiana}}: GSV-tribunen}}) for sponsorship reasons) was further expanded at the back with a lounge for sponsors, classrooms for [[:da:Brøndby Gymnasium
column4: general upper secondary education]]), a public gym, a production kitchen and the sports bar \"''1964''\".<ref name=\"RB Børsen 2006-03-07\">{{cite news
column5: title=Brøndby opfører ny bygning på Brøndby Stadion for 90 mio (Opd)
column11: accessdate=11 April 2020 }}</ref> In addition, spectator conditions were improved upon with six new multi-stalls and three new staircases beneath the East Stand.<ref name=\"9. etape\"/> Two large [[Light-emitting diodes
column12: LED]] screens were also installed during this period.<ref name=\"9. etape\"/> The total cost of the project ran up to DKK 90 million.<ref name=\"RB Børsen 2006-03-07\"/>

column3: KasiGroup]] financed a decoration of the Brøndby Stadion facade;<ref name=\"BT 2014-12-03\">{{cite news
column6: title=Gaver til fødselaren: Det har Brøndby modtaget gennem tiden
column9: date=3 December 2014 }}</ref> yellow, illuminated letters with the stadium name affixed between the roof and the top row of seating at three of the stands.<ref name=\"10. etape\">{{cite web
column13: accessdate=8 December 2012 }}</ref> In addition, each [[gable]] was adorned with four large images that showed [[Brøndby IF]] players and fans in different situations.<ref name=\"10. etape\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: During the winter break in of the [[2017–18 Brøndby IF season
Jasper, Indiana}}: 2017–18 season]], the hole on the South Side-end was closed which meant that an additional 75 seats and extra capacity for 150 standing spectators on terracing were added to the stadium.<ref name=\"TipsSyd\">{{cite web
column4: title=Brøndby-fans betaler selv ombygningen af Sydsiden
column8: author=Lasse Sylvest Mikkelsen}}</ref> The rebuild was financed by the club's fans, through the official fanclub ''[[Brøndby_IF#Support
column9: Brøndby Support]]'' and various unofficial fan groups,<ref name=\"TipsSyd\"/> and through a so-called \"fan fund\" which arose as a result of season tickets and merchandise sales, among other things.<ref name=\"VaerMed\">{{cite web
column11: title=Vær med til at forbedre Sydsiden
column14: work=[[Brøndby IF]]}}</ref> In total, the renovation costs amounted to DKK 450,000, of which the fan fund accounted for DKK 270,000.<ref name=\"TipsSyd\"/><ref name=\"VaerMed\"/> In the summer of 2018, new 256 LED floodlights were installed, produced in China.<ref name=\"Lys2018\">{{cite web
column16: title=Nyt lys skal langtidssikre Brøndby Stadion

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The Brøndby Stadion pitch is surrounded by four covered stands, officially known as Sydsiden (South), GSV-tribunen (East), J. Jensen-tribunen (North) and Carlsberg-tribunen (West). Three stands are all-seaters (except the away section on the North End) while the South End is terracing. Each stand has two tiers.

Sydsiden, literally \"South Side\" in English, was inaugurated as the new South Stand on 29 March 1992 in a match against [[Lyngby Boldklub]], due to a rise in interest for Brøndby IF.<ref name=\"FiB07\"/><ref name=Sydsiden2>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=15 March}}</ref> The lower part of the stand has a standing capacity of 5,600 spectators. Initially, spectators would sit on the terraces,<ref name=Sydsiden>{{cite web
column11: accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref> but younger fans would begin encouraging all fans on Sydsiden to stand up, because they thought that it was easier to sing while standing, which would evolve into the mantra \"sing or piss off\" ({{lang-da
column12: syng eller skrid}}).<ref name=Sydsiden/> This would mark the beginning of a hard-core fan-culture formation on Sydsiden, which has remained ever since, and it is known as the stand in Denmark with the most dedicated and loudest fans when Brøndby plays its home games.<ref name=\"6. etape\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: Until 6 March 2011, Sydsiden was known by its sponsor name, \"Faxe Tribunen\", a subsidiary of [[Royal Unibrew]]. This had to change as there was a conflict of interest as [[Carlsberg Group
Jasper, Indiana}}: Carlsberg]] moved in as new sponsors. Sydsiden was chosen by a panel representing a broad section of the active fan base at Brøndby Stadion, as fans had called the stand this before.<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=4 March 2017}}</ref> Halfway through the 2017–18 season, the hole in the middle of the stand was partly closed, after continuous requests by fans.<ref name=\"VaerMed\"/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: A permanent fanzone was inaugurated outside Sydsiden in 2018 for spectators and fans before, during and after the games. The fanzone is the first of its kind in Scandinavia, and consists of stands for live concerts, bars, foodstands and toilet facilities.

Sydsiden popularised the \"Fenerbahçe greeting\" in Denmark, imported through the transfer of [[Brian Steen Nielsen]] to the Turkish club. A cooperation between goalkeeper [[Mogens Krogh]] and [[Brøndby IF#Support
Jasper, Indiana}}: Brøndby Support]] effectually made the greeting get foothold in Denmark.<ref name=Sydsiden/>

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The North Stand, now known as \"J. Jensen-tribunen\" for sponsorship reasons, was originally known as \"da:OBS!-tribunen\". The lower section of the stand was constructed in 1992 as terracing, and has among fans been known as \"Pølseenden\" ({{lang-da
column3: the sausage end]]}}) due to its former major sponsor, sausage producer Steff-Houlberg. Fans from the away team are assigned a section on this stand, usually in the eastern part of the North Stand, seperated from Brøndby's home fans.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The West Stand, known as \"[[Carlsberg Group
Jasper, Indiana}}: Carlsberg]]-tribunen\", was originally named \"Frisko-tribunen and later also \"SAS-tribunen\" and \"Apollo-tribunen\". The original part of the stand was completed in 1979 as the first stand of the stadium, and it has been preserved through the large expansion in 1999–2000. It can also accommodate a few fans in executive boxes and hospitality suites, and is the ground's main grandstand.

Cleaned up usingAutoEd,safe,Whoisjohngal: The East Stand, now known as \"GSV-tribunen\" for sponsorship reasons, was formerly called \"LOXAM-tribunen\", \"[[Codan]]-tribunen and \"DNE-tribunen\". The lower section of the stand was constructed in 1982 and 1990. The East Stand was originally without a roof, and consisted of terraces. Today, it is the largest stand of Brøndby Stadion with a total of 34 rows of seats. In 2006, a larger extension was established behind the stand from the facade, consisting of sponsor facilities, a sports bar and classrooms for Brøndby Gymnasium. The classrooms were inaugurated on 8 January 2007. In April 2018, a new family lounge was opened behind the East Stand with both physical and Esports facilities.

The easiest way of getting to the stadium with public transport is with the [[S-tog]] or S-train. Line B (green) will stop at both Brøndbyøster and Glostrup stations, where there are shuttle buses on match days. One can also walk from the stations, with the walk taking 15 minutes from Glostrup, and slightly longer from Brøndbyøster.
Brøndby Stadion has been used five times as home ground for the [[Denmark national football team
Jasper, Indiana}}: Danish national team]]. Further it has been the venue of four youth national matches and a league national match:<ref>{{cite web
